characters: A STREAM OF CRYSTAL BLUE WATER

dialogues.speaker: BLINDING WHITENESS
dialogues.text: We hear a MAN GASPING softly. Rhythmically. A LUMINOUS PALE SHAPE slowly forms out of the searing whiteness. Gradually we realize we’re moving across the ALABASTER BODY of a WOMAN. Her skin translucent.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE WOMAN'S FACE
dialogues.text: Ethereal. Her eyes closed. Her face lifeless. Then... ..-her eyes open. She looks straight at us with unseeing pale blue eyes. This is ANNA (late 20s). We pull back. PAUL (30s) makes love to Anna. Their movements perfunctory. Passionless. He turns to look at her. Realizes she’s not there. He suddenly stops. Rolls off her. Sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Nothing. Anna leans down and picks up her RED SLIP from the floor.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (sighs wearily) You used to enjoy it. Now it’s... He shakes his head. Frustrated. Lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: ...it's like fucking a corpse. Paul immediately realizes he’s gone too far. Turns to Ann

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Shit. I’m sorry. That was-- Anna gets out of bed. Walks towards the bathroom. Paul puts his head in his hands. INT. PAUL’S APARTMENT. BATHROOM —- MOMENTS LATER Through the fogged shower partition we see the blurred ghostly figure of Anna. Paul walks in.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Anna. I’m sorry. That was a stupid thing to say. But you know sometimes... sometimes it’s like you’re not here anymore. Like you're somewhere else.  Anna doesn’t reply.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Is this about us?

dialogues.speaker: ON ANNA
dialogues.text: her head bowed as she lets the water wash over her.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It’s not about us.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Then what is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I just want us to be happy. Anna doesn't move. We sense the emptiness inside her.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Are you happy? She closes her eyes. Forces herself to reply.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m happy.

dialogues.speaker: A DROP OF BLOOD
dialogues.text: falls into the water. Then another drop.

dialogues.speaker: ON ANNA
dialogues.text: her nose is bleeding. She touches her lips. Looks impassively at the blood on her fingertips. The SOUND OF WATER carries into the next scene... FADE TO WHITE.

dialogues.speaker: A STREAM OF CRYSTAL BLUE WATER
dialogues.text: A MAN’S HANDS penetrate the water. Thin and elegant. Perfectly manicured. Turning slowly as he washes them meticulously. He picks up a crisply folded white towel. Dries his hands carefully. Snaps on white latex gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful morning. We move through a tranquil cemetery. Pastoral and idyllic. Dappled light falls through old trees onto statues of grieving angels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A path leads to an old well-kept house. Amongst a blaze o violet tulips we see a sign: Eliot Deane. Funeral Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun streams into an elegant wood-panelled room. The Funeral Director, ELIOT DEANE (40s) guides MRS. AYRES (70s) past caskets tastefully arranged on faux-marble pedestals. He’s a serene man. Quiet and professional.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: The Antique Carlisle. Solid cherry. (strokes the wood lovingly) Hand rubbed satin finish. Tufted sovereign interior. Eternal-Rest adjustable mattress with matching pillow. He gestures to a metal casket.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Or perhaps the Aegean? Solid bronze exterior. Hand brushed finish with Grecian bronze highlights.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. AYRES
dialogues.text: The Antique Carlisle. Definitely the Antique Carlisle.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (writes in his notebook) Excellent choice. Mrs. Ayres caresses the soft velvet trimming.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. AYRES
dialogues.text: An antique coffin for an antique lady. We suit each other.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (smiles) You'll look beautiful. (beat) Now about the service. Would you like a private visitation? Mrs. Ayres is miles away.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Ayres?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. AYRES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Yes. A private visitation. (hesitates) Mr. Deane? What happens when we die?  Eliot chooses his words carefully.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: It’s different every time. Each person dies in their own way. INT/EXT. ANNA’S CAR - MORNING Anna drives past the strip malls of a small suburban town in a GREEN TOYOTA. On the dashboard a KITSCHY BOBBLEHEAD DOLL nods its head from side to side. Anna pulls up to a red light. Glances across at the other cars. We see the vacant faces of COMMUTERS staring blankly into space. The light changes. Anna hasn’t noticed. The car behind her HONKS in frustration. She quickly pulls out... ++. just as a SUV turns in front of her. She slams on her brakes. Hard. Missing the SUV by inches. The DRIVER screams at her. His face contorted in ugly rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna locks her car. Heads towards the main building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Classes have started. JACK (11), a serious looking boy, walks through a silent corridor. Up ahead two OLDER BOYS, a TALL KID and a KID with ACNE, push a GEEKY BOY against a locker. Jack tries to pass by unnoticed.

dialogues.speaker: TALL KID
dialogues.text: Hey. Jack-off! Jack walks faster. The two Older Boys set off after him. He darts into a corridor. Ducks into an empty classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack waits anxiously by the door. It looks like he’s lost the bullies. Then a sudden rustling noise makes him jump. He turns. TINY CHICKS huddle in a plastic incubator on a table. Jack moves over to them.

dialogues.speaker: TALL KID, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Didn’t you hear me Jack-off? Jack swivels round. The Tall Kid walks towards him as the Acne Kid guards the door. Jack doesn’t reply.

dialogues.speaker: ACNE KID
dialogues.text: He must be deaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You deaf Jack-off? Jack ignores them. Irritating the Tall Kid even more.

dialogues.speaker: TALL KID
dialogues.text: Can’t fucking speak either. He pushes Jack against the table, toppling the incubator. Panicked, the CHICKS scatter across the surface. Just then the door opens. Anna walks in.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What's going on? She glances at the Older Boys then at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Jack?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Nothing Miss Bryant.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Nothing? The incubator didn’t just fall by itself. The Older Boys stare at Jack. Waiting for his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I tripped. It was an accident. Anna looks at Jack carefully. She knows he’s lying.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (to the Older Boys) Show’s over. Get to your classes. (to Jack) Jack. Help me clear up. Jack doesn’t hear her. He’s mesmerized by a SOLITARY CHICK standing motionless in the corner of the incubator.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I think it’s dead. Anna reaches in. Tenderly picks up the chick.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No. The poor thing’s just scared. INT. ELEMENTARY SCHOOL. TEACHERS’ COMMON ROOM —- DAY School’s over. Anna listlessly corrects a stack of exercise books. She can’t focus. Pulls out a BOTTLE OF PILLS. Shakes a pill into her hand. Swallows it dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul works with half a dozen COLLEAGUES around a large conference table covered with documents and thick files. He reaches across to a pizza box. It’s empty.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: OK. Who took the last pepperoni? A PREPPY GUY slides across another pizza box.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Great. Broccoli. (lifts out a slice) Who the fuck ordered broccoli? NEAL, a thin pallid guy, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: NEAL
dialogues.text: Oh that’s just disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: PREPPY GUY
dialogues.text: What's wrong with vegetarian pizza? It’s healthy.

dialogues.speaker: NEAL
dialogues.text: Pizza isn’t supposed to be healthy. Paul glances at his watch. Suddenly realizes the time. He quickly picks up his cell phone. Heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: NEAL
dialogues.text: You ordering in another pizza?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah. With wheatgrass and alfalfa sprouts. Everyone laughs.

dialogues.speaker: PREPPY GUY
dialogues.text: (mutters ) Yeah. Yeah. Smart asses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul walks into the corridor dialling his cell phone. INT. ELEMENTARY SCHOOL. TEACHERS’ COMMON ROOM - SAME TIME Anna’s cell phone rings as she closes her locker. She fishes it out from her bag as she heads to the door. Checks the ID. Hesitates. Then takes the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul cups his cell. Worried he'll be overheard.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hi baby. I’m really sorry about this morning. I fucked up. I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna steps into an empty corridor.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) We still on for tonight? (beat) Anna?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don’t know Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul’s anxious. We sense he’s hiding something.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Please Anna. It took me weeks to get the table.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Maybe we can change it to Thursday--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No. It has to be tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Paul? What’s the matter? Paul tries hard to cover his nervousness. Forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nothing. Don’t worry. I just need... I just want us to have dinner tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite Paul’s reassurances Anna is clearly worried now.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (hesitates) OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered) Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul hesitates. Lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And Anna. Everything’s going to be fine.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Promise?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna slips her phone back into her bag as she walks through the deserted corridor. Her high heels echo loudly in the eerie quietness. Suddenly one of the fluorescent ceiling lights behind her blows out with a loud WHUMPH. Anna starts. Turns. WHUMPH. The next light dies. Anna quickens her step. The lights go off one by one. The darkness quickly creeping up behind her. There’s only one light still on as she reaches the exit. She looks up. The light flickers. But then strangely stays on. Bathing her ina cold pool of light. Anna’s unsettled. She turns and frantically pushes the door. It doesn’t open. She pushes hard with both hands. Nothing. It’s locked. She turns back slowly. The darkness around her impenetrable. Almost viscous. She reaches out... ... her hand DISAPPEARS into the thick blackness. Anna snatches her hand back. Stares at it. Then we hear the sound of SLOW FOOTSTEPS. Moving deliberately towards her.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (nervously) Hello? Her voice echoes down the silent corridor. She glimpses something move in the blackness.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Is someone there?  A BLACK SHAPE materializes inside the darkness. Silent. Brooding. Anna can’t move. Terrified. Suddenly the corridor’s flooded with a BLINDING WHITE LIGHT. Anna's dazzled. Shades her eyes with her hand. As she tentatively pulls her hand away... ...it’s only Jack. His hand on the light switch.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Jack!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Did I scare you Miss Bryant? Jack moves over to the door.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It’s locked. He gently pushes against the door. The door slowly opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, still shaken, walks with Jack towards the parking l

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t you be home?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: My mom’s picking me up. (beat) It’s my birthday. We're going to MacDonald’s. Then on Saturday my mom’s taking me to Busch Gardens. We’re going to ride the Alpengeist. (earnestly) Continually voted one of the top ten roller coaster rides in America, the Alpengeist is a breathtaking avalanche of adventure.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (tries to keep a straight-face) I didn’t know the park was open yet.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: My mom’s friends with the manager. They’re opening it specially for me. She knows he’s lying again. Smiles sadly.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Sounds like fun.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yes. It will be fun.  10. They reach Anna’s car. Stand in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Jack. Those boys. Do they bother you a lot? Jack hesitates. Then slowly nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You know you can always talk to me about it if you want to. He nods. Anna‘’s clearly worried about him.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You sure you don’t need a ride? Jack shakes his head. Anna glances at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Well. I better run.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I have to go to a funeral. My old piano teacher.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (with sudden interest) Can I come?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No Jack. Funerals are very private affairs.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’ve never been to a funeral.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It wouldn’t be appropriate Jack. Anyway wouldn’t your mom worry about you?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Not really.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m sure she would. I’11 see you tomorrow in class. Have a wonderful birthday. Jack nods disappointed. Anna watches him walk away then gets in her car.  11. INT. ANNA’S CAR —- MOMENTS LATER Anna slips her key into the ignition. Loud music suddenly blares from the car radio. She switches it off. Squeezes the bridge of her nose. She pulls out a bottle of pills from her bag. It’s empty. She rummages in the glove compartment. Finds another bottle. Empty. She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits on the bench. Watches Anna drive away. Then unzips his backpack. Something moves inside. A strange jerky movement. Jack closes the backpack. Glances up and down the empty street. Then walks away on his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna steps out of the Pharmacy. As she washes down a pill with a bottle of water she notices a small Hair Salon. Looks critically at herself in the Pharmacy window. Anna moves over to the Salon. Reaches for the door handle... then hesitates. She’s about to walk away when the Salon door suddenly opens. Anna smiles shyly as a freshly COIFFURED WOMAN politely holds the door for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna leans back against a washbasin. Her neck tightly cradled against the white porcelain. The light's harsh and not particularly flattering. She closes her eyes. Behind her the HANDS of a HAIRDRESSER in latex gloves begin to rinse dye from Anna’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: ON SINK
dialogues.text: Startling white. A stream of water flows into the sink. Then after a moment the spiralling clear water gradually turns a deep crimson red. INT. MOTHER’S HOUSE. HALLWAY - DAY Anna closes the front door behind her. She smiles as she catches her reflection in the hallway mirror. Her hair a dark vibrant red. Just then, from another room, we hear an OLD WOMAN'S hacking cough.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Anna? Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes Mother.  12. INT. MOTHER’S HOUSE. BEDROOM - MOMENTS LATER Anna's mother, BEATRICE (50s), sits in bed, knitting with swift, violent precision. The bedside table’s stacked with medication. She’s clearly been bed-ridden for some time. An electric wheelchair in the corner of the room. Anna appears at the door. Beatrice scrutinizes her for a second. Then returns to her knitting.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Terrible color. Anna moves to the beside table. Picks up a dirty plate.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Can I get you something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: I’m not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You have to eat.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: I don’t have to do anything.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: The doctor said--

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: The doctor’s an idiot. He doesn’t know what he’s talking about. Anna sighs. Trying hard not to let her Mother provoke her. Beatrice glances up. Anna avoids her look.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Why did you do it? Today of all days.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What have I done wrong this time? Anna goes to the window. Draws back the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: You've forgotten haven’t you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No I haven’t forgotten. The service isn’t till six.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Then you’ve got plenty of time to wash it out.  13.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It’s permanent. You can’t wash it out.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Then dye it back. You can’t show up at the funeral looking like that. Like some prostitute.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don’t look--

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Don’t argue with me. Why are you constantly arguing with me? Anna bites her tongue. Heads to the door.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: To do the washing up.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: The sheets need changing. They haven’t been changed in months.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I changed them Monday. Anna goes to the cupboard. Takes out clean sheets.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: You weren’t here Monday. You never sleep at home anymore. What if something happened to me in the middle of the night?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Nothing is going to happen to you. Anyway Diane--

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: (snorts) Fat lot of good she is. I wouldn’t have to pay for a Nurse if my only daughter wasn’t living in sin with that lawyer of hers. Doing God knows what. They always leave you in the end. You'll see. Just like your father--

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: That’s enough Mother! Anna dumps the sheets on the bed. As she turns to leave Beatrice’s hand darts out and grabs Anna’s wrist.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: That’s it. Go and cry to Paul.  14. Anna pulls herself free. Moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Go and bitch to Paul about your mean old mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A warm intimate room. Peaceful. Rows of chairs filled with ELDERLY MOURNERS. Eliot stands respectfully beside a casket. FATHER GRAHAM (50s) reads at a lectern.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER GRAHAM
dialogues.text: We have entrusted our brother James Hutton to God's mercy in sure and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, in a black dress, walks quickly along the gravel driveway. She stops. Stares out over the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER GRAHAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...certain hope of the resurrection to eternal life through our Lord Jesus Christ, who died and rose again for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna slips into the back of the room. Eliot leads MRS. HUTTON (60s) to the body of her husband, JAMES HUTTON (70S), lying in the casket. Mrs. Hutton touches a bouquet of white roses by the casket.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUTTON
dialogues.text: White roses. They were his favorite. How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: They just seemed appropriate somehow.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUTTON
dialogues.text: He looks so peaceful. As if he's only sleeping. Anna approaches Mrs. Hutton. She doesn’t notice Eliot watching her carefully.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hutton. I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUTTON
dialogues.text: Thank you Anna. You were always his favorite student.  15. Anna smiles awkwardly. Uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUTTON
dialogues.text: How’s your mother?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Fine. She sends her condolences.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUTTON
dialogues.text: You look tired dear.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No. I’m fine. Everything’s fine. But we can see in her eyes that everything’s not fine. Mrs. Hutton nods, then turns to greet another MOURNER. Anna steps nervously up to the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Hutton lies peacefully amongst the velvet trimming. Suddenly his LIPS PART... as he GASPS SOFTLY.

dialogues.speaker: VIEWING ROOM
dialogues.text: Anna steps back terrified. Stares at Hutton. His face serene again. It must have been her imagination. She glances up quickly. Embarrassed. Eliot’s still observing her. He nods to her cordially. INT. FUNERAL HOME. ELIOT’S ROOM - DAY A spartan room at the top of the house. Eliot carefully pins a POLAROID of Hutton lying in a coffin to the wall. Next to Hutton’s photograph, we briefly glimpse the edge of ANOTHER POLAROID. Eliot stares intently at Hutton’s image for a moment, then takes off his jacket and moves to the window. ELIOT’S POV Anna’s by her car rummaging in a bag for her keys. Getting increasingly frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna suddenly looses it. Angrily dumps the contents of her bag onto the driveway. She kneels down. Grabs the keys. Throws the rest of her things back into the bag. She stands. Leans against the car. She looks weary. She glances up at the sky desperately trying to hold back her tears. Black storm clouds gather on the horizon.  16. Anna brusquely wipes away her eyes with the back of her hand. Pulls herself together. Angry with herself. INT. FUNERAL HOME. ELIOT’S ROOM - DAY Eliot watches intently as Anna drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sits at a window table. It's raining hard outside. He glances at his watch then nervously checks his pockets. Pulls out a RING BOX. He looks at it for a moment then slips it back into his pocket. As he refills his glass, Anna appears outside holding her raincoat above her head. She stares at Paul for a moment through the window marbled with rain. Paul suddenly notices Anna at the window. He starts. Spills some of his red wine on his shirt. CLOSE on the red stain. It unfurls like a flower. Spreading out over the white material.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Sorry about that. Paul dabs the stain with a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You scared the life out of me. Anna laughs as she sits down. Paul looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your hair.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You don't like it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I didn't say that. It's just very... red. I mean it's not really you is it? A WAITER appears at the table before Anna can reply.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Are you ready to order?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes. We'll have the duck.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Paul.  17.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What? You always have the duck here.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (picks up the menu) I don't always have the duck. Paul shrugs. Pours Anna some wine as she looks through the menu. The Waiter taps his pen on his pad impatiently. Anna sighs. Puts the menu aside.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I'll have the duck. Paul smiles as the Waiter leaves. Anna tries to ignore him. But after a second she can't help smiling back.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The duck is very good. Anna's smile broadens. The tension between them broken for the moment. Paul reaches across. Touches her hand.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Let’s not argue tonight. OK?

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Anna takes a sip of wine.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: This is good. She picks up the bottle. Checks the label.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: And looks very expensive... (smiles questioningly) What’s the special occasion? Paul’s momentarily thrown. He tries to cover it by rearranging his napkin. Anna notices.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (suddenly very serious) Actually there is something I need to talk to you about. Now Anna’s nervous.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’ve been offered a transfer to head office in Chicago. Anna looks down. Stares at her hands on the table.  18.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’‘ll mean more work of course. More responsibility. A lot of changes. But it’s an incredible opportunity. I’d be crazy to turn it down. And... (nervous ) ---well I’ve been thinking. Maybe it’s time for us to... Paul pauses as he reaches inside his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (without looking up) You’re going to leave me. Paul’s stunned. Speechless. Before he can say anything--

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You could've just told me this morning. You didn’t need to buy me off with an expensive meal. Paul reaches for her hand. Anna gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Anna wait.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Why did you lie to me? You promised everything was going to be OK.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (increasingly frustrated) Don’t be ridiculous. Anna. You’ve got it all wrong.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m not being ridiculous. Why do you always talk to me like I'm a small child?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (as if talking to a small child) Anna.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: See? There you go again. Do you know how irritating that is?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (loses it) Jesus. Can't we just have one fucking meal without arguing--

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Fuck you! The other DINERS turn and stare at them. Paul glances at them embarrassed. Anna doesn’t notice. Upset.  19.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Keep your voice down, everyone’s watching.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You’re crazy. You know that? Just like your mother.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m nothing like my mother! Anna grabs her coat. Pushes her way through the restauran

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (stands) I’m not running after you this time Anna.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Good. Paul’s suddenly aware that everyone’s looking at him. He quickly sits down. Drains his glass of wine. Furious. INT/EXT. ANNA’S CAR - NIGHT Anna closes the car door. It’s still raining hard outside Her hair, perfect minutes ago, is now bedraggled. Her mak up’s running. She places her hands on the steering wheel. Trying desperately to pull herself together. Suddenly. THUMP. Anna jumps. Turns. Paul’s at the car window. He thumps the glass again. Anna hits the locks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul grabs the door handle.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Anna. Open the door. Please. I want you to come with me. I want to... INT/EXT. ANNA’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Anna can’t hear him above the sound of the RAIN HAMMERING onto the car. She shakes her head. Puts the car in drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul stumbles aside as Anna’s car pulls away. She stops at the parking lot exit a short distance away.  20. INT/EXT. ANNA’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Anna looks up into the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: ON REARVIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: Paul stands forlornly in the rain. Their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA'S CAR
dialogues.text: She hesitates. For a moment we think she might go back to him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +--+. but then Anna pulls out and drives away. Leaving Pa alone in the parking lot. The rain pounding the asphalt. INT/EXT. ANNA’S CAR. HIGHWAY - NIGHT Anna peers through the blurred windshield as the wipers battle with the TORRENTIAL DOWNPOUR. A LARGE TRUCK plows past menacingly on the rain-slicked highway. Anna’s still upset. She wipes away her tears. On the dashboard the kitschy doll bobs its head from side to side. Anna picks up her cell phone. Glances down as she dials a number. She looks up... a WHITE VAN with black tinted windows cuts in front of he

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Shit! Anna swerves into the next lane. We hear the blaring horn from the car behind her.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (into rear-view mirror) OK. OK. I saw you. (muttering) Jerk. The cell phone connects. We hear Paul’s answering machine

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Paul? You home yet? Can you pick up? I just don’t want it to end like this. Anna drops the phone into her bag on the passenger seat. Wipes away the mist on the inside of the glass. A TRACTOR TRAILER shudders past loaded with metal pipes.  21.

dialogues.speaker: ON METAL PIPES
dialogues.text: The badly loaded pipes BANG OMINOUSLY against each other. CUT TO BLACK. INT. FUNERAL HOME. ELIOT’S ROOM - EARLY MORNING Darkness. A bright light comes on. CLOSE ON a MAN'S HANDS. Turning slowly under a stream of crystal blue water. We pull back. Eliot dries his hands. Opens a cabinet. Takes out a pair of latex gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large room. Tall vaulted ceilings. White tiles. Soft morning light seeps in from a small round window set high on one wall. The room is silent. Still. Like a chapel. In the semi-darkness we see a BODY on a porcelain slab covered with a white sheet. We hear a key turn in a lock. Then another lock. The room’s suddenly flooded with a harsh white light. Eliot steps inside the room. He takes off his jacket. Carefully places it on a coat-hanger. Puts on a pale blue smock then snaps on the latex gloves. His every move meticulous. Measured. Like a ritual. Eliot walks over to the slab, his surgery clogs softly clacking against the tiled floor. He looks at the slab for a moment then slowly pulls the sheet away revealing... ANNA'S BODY. Pale and lifeless. An ugly gash above her eyebrow. Cracked violet lips. A rip in her black dress soaked with a dark stain. She’s only wearing one shoe. Eliot gently takes off the watch from her stiff wrist. Places it inside a brown paper bag. Eases off the shoe. Picks up a scalpel from a tray of instruments on a steel trolley. Delicately slices open her dress. Peels it off. He's about to cut the straps of her RED SLIP when... Anna OPENS HER EYES. She looks straight at us with unseeing pale blue eyes. Strangely Eliot's not surprised. He calmly steps back. Watches her carefully. Anna’s eyes slowly focus on Eliot. She’s groggy. Confused  22.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Where am I? She talks with difficulty. Her breathe labored.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You're in a funeral home. (beat) You’re dead. Anna’s vacant eyes widen in shock. She struggles to sit up but she can’t even raise her head. Her body stiff. Rigid. Eliot speaks to her calmly. Soothingly.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You had a car accident. It was raining. You hit a truck loaded with metal pipes. She looks fearfully at the bloodied dress in Eliot’s hand

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m not dead.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You were pronounced dead eight hours ago. Your blood no longer circulates through your body. Your brain cells are slowly dying. Your body’s already decomposing.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m not dead. Eliot looks at her sadly for a moment. He places the bloodied dress on the trolley. Then picks up a document. Holds it up for her.

dialogues.speaker: ON DOCUMENT
dialogues.text: It’s Anna’s death certificate.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: This is your death certificate. Cause of death. Massive internal trauma. Time of death. 8.23PM.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You were dead on arrival. The attending physician signed here... (points to document) -.-at 9.45 last night. I picked up your body from the hospital morgue at 12.10 this morning. Anna stares with horror at her death certificate, then at Eliot. He looks away. It pains him to see her so distressed.  23.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Eliot picks up a sponge from the trolley. Wets it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Who are you? Eliot delicately washes Anna’s face. She doesn’t flinch as he dabs the wound above her eye brow.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Don’t touch me! Why are you touching me?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’m preparing your body. You have to look beautiful for your funeral.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m not dead. Eliot sighs wearily. As if he’d had this conversation many times before.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You all say the same thing. (beat) I’m sorry. Maybe you should rest now. Eliot peels off his latex gloves and heads for the door. As he hangs his pale blue smock on the peg he turns and looks at Anna for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ON ANNA
dialogues.text: The lights go off. 0O.S. the door clicks shut as it locks automatically behind Eliot.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (softly) I can’t be dead. It’s just a nightmare. I’ll wake up soon. Wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul wakes up. Badly hung-over. Still in his clothes. Sunlight streams into the room. Blinding him. He reaches across. The bed's empty. He’s surprised for a moment then remembers the argument the night before. He gets up. Sits on the edge of the bed. Lights a cigarette. He notices his jacket on the floor. lLeans down. As he pulls out the BlackBerry from his jacket, the RING BOX falls onto the floor. Paul doesn’t notice.  24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul steps into the kitchen. Nervously checking his BlackBerry. Nothing. Just then he sees the red light blinking on his answer machine. He presses play.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Paul? You home yet? Can you pick up? I just don’t want it to end like this. Paul’s relieved. He picks up the phone. Dials. We hear the ringing on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two technicians, an OLD GUY and his YOUNG PALE ASSISTANT, push a NAKED BODY wrapped in plastic through the morgue. They jump as they hear the MUFFLED sound of a cell phone. The ringing comes from a bag speckled with blood lying on a table (we recognize it as Anna’s bag). The Assistant walks over. Takes out the cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: It’s the schoolteacher’s. From the car crash. Should I answer it? The ringing stops abruptly. It’s suddenly very silent.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Someone's in for a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY
dialogues.text: How many times do I have to tell you? You can’t leave their stuff laying around. It should've been returned to the family.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: I’ve been busy, OK. (muttering) Like she’s really going to need her rollover minutes now. As the Assistant reaches for the bag, he notices a solitary shoe on the table. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: What shall I do with this?

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY
dialogues.text: Where’s the other one? The Assistant looks round. He can’t see the other shoe anywhere. He turns to the Old Guy and shrugs.  25.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY
dialogues.text: Just burn it. You can’t send them back one shoe. It’s not respectful. INT. PAUL’S APARTMENT. KITCHEN - SAME TIME We hear a BEEP.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (on phone) You got it all wrong baby. I want you to come to Chicago with me. Look. I'll swing by your place on my way to the office. You know I love you. EXT. MOTHER’S HOUSE - DAY Paul pulls up to a suburban house. Walks quickly to the door, a supermarket bouquet of flowers wrapped in cellophane in his hand. He rings the bell. No-one answers. He rings again. Knocks hard on the door.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Anna! Still no answer. Paul looks around. Notices the driveway’s empty. He heads back to his car. INT/EXT. PAUL’S CAR - MOMENTS LATER Paul’s on his cell phone as he drives. He gets Anna’s voice mail again.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (into phone) It’s me again. I must have just missed you at home. Call me when you get this. OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul strides down an empty corridor. The flowers in his hand. Searching for Anna’s classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TEACHER stands in front of the class holding a shell.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: ... the shell grows slowly... The door opens. Paul steps into the classroom. His smile fades as he realizes it’s not Anna.  26.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh hi. I’m looking for Anna Bryant. The Teacher quickly moves over. Hustles Paul to the door.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: (indignant) I’m sorry but you just can’t--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m Anna‘s... fiancée. Paul Conran. I thought this was her class. The Teacher glances suspiciously at the flowers in his ha

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We had a little misunderstanding last night.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: (hesitates) She didn’t come in today. Jack’s in the front row. Following the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did she call in sick?

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: She hasn’t called in at all. It’s not like her. She always calls in. Paul’s worried now. Something’s wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna lies rigidly on the slab. Her head turned to one side. Staring blankly at the wall. Her eyes glazed. Suddenly classical music fills the room. Anna frowns. Disoriented. She moves her head with difficulty. Nervously looks around. For a moment she doesn’t know where she is. Then she sees Eliot by a CD player. She watches with trepidation as he approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Please don’t hurt me.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (smiles) How can I hurt you? You’re already dead.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: But I’m not dead.  27.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Then why are you here? Anna doesn’t know what to say. She turns her head away. A tear falls down her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Please. Just let me go. I won’t go to the police. I won’t tell anyone. Eliot moves her head back. Gently wipes away her tear.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You’re still in denial. You have to trust me. I’m only here to help you. Eliot slides a wooden head-rest under her neck and studie her wounds, touching them delicately. Thinking about how to conceal them. He turns to a tray of instruments. Picks up a needle. Leans over Anna. The needle pierces her brow. Sliding cleanly through her skin. She doesn’t feel any pain as Eliot carefully sews the wound. He’s meticulous. Clearly very good at his job. Eliot glances at his watch. Picks up a SYRINGE and an AMPOULE OF AMBER LIQUID. Draws up the amber liquid. Anna’s alarmed. She tries to pull back.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Don’t be scared.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: This will relax your muscles. Stop the rigor mortis setting in so I can work on your body. He INJECTS Anna in the neck. Just then we hear a car pull up on the gravel driveway outside.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (to himself) Your mother's early. Anna‘s eyelids feel very heavy. Slowly her eyes close. Eliot pulls the white sheet over her body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Nurse, DIANE (30s) follows Beatrice in her wheelchair as Eliot leads them through the hallway.  28.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I'm so very sorry Mrs. Bryant. It’s always so tragic when you lose a child.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: I lost her years ago. He glances at her curiously. Then gestures to his office.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: If you'd care to come to my office we can discuss the arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: I want to see her.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: But she hasn’t been--

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: I don’t care. I want to see her. It takes him a second to respond.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatrice leans against the slab staring at Anna’s covered body. Eliot stands respectfully to one side. In the b.g. Diane shivers. The room’s cold. Beatrice touches Anna’s hand through the white sheet. Then uncovers Anna’s face. The needle’s still embedded in her eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Ah. Forgive me. Eliot quickly steps forward. Pulls out the needle. Cuts the thread with a pair of large scissors.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: As I said. I’ve only just started preparing her.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: What's the point of preserving the body if the soul's already left?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (quietly to himself) No. The soul never leaves. Beatrice stares at Anna.  29.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: It’s us who are left behind. It's us who suffer. (to Anna) Who’s going to look after me now? Did you think about that? She nods to Diane. Diane helps her into the wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’1l confirm the date with Father Graham this afternoon. Friday as you requested.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Just do what you think's best. It’s just details. Beatrice whirs towards the door. She suddenly stops. Turns to Eliot.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Oh there is one thing.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: Her hair. She was a brunette. I'd like it back to that color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot watches Beatrice’s car drive away. INT/EXT. PAUL’S CAR - DAY Paul waits in his car outside the Mother’s house. The wilting flowers on the passenger seat beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatrice’s car pulls up. Diane gets out. Pulls the wheelchair out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL'S CAR
dialogues.text: Paul grabs the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul strides over as Diane helps Beatrice into her wheelchair.  30.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bryant. Beatrice doesn’t acknowledge him. Paul turns to Diane.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hi Diane. I need to talk to Anna. Diane can’t look him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I think you better come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beatrice sits in her wheelchair with her back to the door. Paul stops a short distance away.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What happened? Where’s Anna?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: (without turning) Anna was in a car accident last night. My daughter’s dead. That's what happened. Paul stares at Beatrice’s back in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: A car crash? When? Beatrice turns her wheelchair round to face Paul.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: (irritably) I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: They said it happened just before 8.30.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: But... we were at the restaurant... Beatrice glares at him. She clearly blames him for Anna’s death.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t have let her drive in that weather. Paul looks down guiltily at the flowers in his hand.  31.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No. She can’t be dead. There must be some mistake.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: There’s no mistake. We just got back from the funeral home. Beatrice pushes a joystick on her wheelchair. As she whirs past Paul she notices the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: (dryly) . Flowers? How appropriate. Paul’s not listening anymore. Stunned.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you call me?

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: You took her away from me. I don’t want you anywhere near her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot turns on the taps. Fills a copper kettle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. 0.S. a shuddering pipe bangs ominously. Anna opens her eyes abruptly as if waking from a deep sleep. She stares at us. Numb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON an exploding BLUE FLAME from a gas ring. We pull back. Eliot places a kettle on the ring. Then measures out exactly two spoons of tea from an ornate tin into a teapot. Meticulous in everything he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Anna’s hand. Her fingers FLEX slightly. She pushes herself up awkwardly. Suddenly realizes something. She touches her wrist. Desperately searching for her pulse. Then frantically checks her neck. Panicking. She can’t find her heartbeat. She stares at her hand. Then abruptly SLAMS it against the slab. Hard. She feels no pain. She does it again. Harder. Still nothing.  32.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I must be in shock. That’s all. It’s just shock. She struggles to her feet. Stumbles groggily to the door. Tries the door handle. It’s locked. She bangs on the door feebly. Then she hears something. She cocks her head. Follows the sound of Eliot’s footsteps upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (hoarse) Let me out! INT. FUNERAL HOME. ELIOT’S OFFICE - DAY Eliot’s by his desk. Checking his appointment book. Whistling softly to himself. We can’t hear Anna’s cries. He pours a cup of tea. Adds a drop of milk. As he stirs his tea, he hears the sound of feet CRUNCHING on the gravel outside. He glances out the window. ELIOT’S POV Paul stands in the middle of the driveway staring blankly at the Funeral Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot steps out of the Funeral Home. Heads towards Paul.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Can I help you? Paul turns to him. Pulled away from his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Mr. Deane?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: My name’s Conran. Paul Conran. Eliot smiles. Holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Of course. The lawyer. (off Paul’s surprised look) It’s a small town. In my line of work you get to know everyone eventually. As they shake, Eliot looks at Paul’s hand strangely. As if he senses something.  33.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m Anna Bryant’s fiancée.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: That’s strange. She wasn’t wearing an engagement ring.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well not quite fiancée...

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’m very sorry for your loss Mr. Conran.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’d like to see her.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’m afraid the viewing isn’t until--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’d need to see her now. If that’s possible.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. It’s not possible. You're not family and--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Please. It’d only take a minute.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I understand. But--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: NO. YOU DON’T UNDERSTAND!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna suddenly hears Paul’s loud voice outside.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (weakly) Paul! I’m here! Paul! She frantically beats her fists against the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul quickly controls his anger. His eyes smart with tear

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I tried to stop her. She didn’t hear me. Paul’s voice breaks with emotion. He can’t go on. Eliot gently takes him by the elbow. Leads him back to his car.  34.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Mr. Conran. There really is nothing I can do. I’m so sorry. Paul looks defeated. He simply nods his head. Eliot watches him get into his car and drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sits by the door in the darkness. Suddenly the room’s flooded with light. Eliot walks in. Looks at Anna for a moment. She just stares back at him coldly. He heads over to the sink.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: No one.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No one? A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: It was Paul.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (calmly) I know. I heard you talking to him. Why didn’t you let him see me? Eliot smiles. Amused she caught him out. He continues washing his hands.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Did you love him? Anna looks up sharply. Eliot’s clearly hit a nerve.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: That’s none of your business. Eliot shrugs. Dries his hands on a white towel.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You weren’t going to tell me Paul was here, were you?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Why not?  35.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Because it would only hurt you. You have to let go of the living. Just like they have to let go of you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you. Why are you doing this to me? He shakes his head as he drops the towel into a small bin

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You’re all the same. You all blame me for your death. As if it were my fault.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No. You drugged me. So my mother wouldn’t--

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: The others. They just see you as a dead body on a slab. Only I can see you as you really are.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You’re crazy! Eliot’s taken aback. Hurt.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’m a busy man. I don’t have time for this. He heads to the door. Pulls out his keys and unlocks it. Just then he remembers something. Turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Oh I nearly forgot. How tall are you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What!? He looks her up and down. Gauging her height.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Five seven.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Why. .?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I need to know how tall you are. For your coffin. Anna’s stunned. Eliot looks at her for a moment. Then switches off the main lights.  36.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Wait! He ignores her. The door CLICKS shut behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot steps into the hallway. Stops by a vase of flowers. He plucks a dead petal. Crushes it. Curiously sniffs his fingers. Then heads to the casket room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Anna’s face. She looks empty. Dispirited. Just then something catches her attention... The light from the window glints off a pair of LARGE SCISSORS on the steel trolley. Anna stumbles to the trolley. Feeling her way through the semi-darkness. Grabs the scissors. Just then she notices a BODY, covered with a white sheet, lying on a gurney in the corner. She turns away. Scared. But then, almost against her will, she approaches the gurney. As if drawn to the body. She slowly pulls the sheet away... The dead body of an OLD WOMAN. Staring blindly at Anna with cloudy opaque eyes. Long greasy gray hair. Shaken, Anna pushes herself against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Oh God. Please. I don’t want to die. INT. JACK’S HOUSE. KITCHEN - DAY Jack carefully cuts something out of a local newspaper. The loud sounds of a TV blare from another room.

dialogues.speaker: ON NEWSPAPER
dialogues.text: Schoolteacher Dies in Tragic Car Crash. INT. JACK’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER The curtains are drawn. JACK’S MOTHER sits in an armchair with her back to us watching TV. Jack walks in.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You were supposed to pick me up from school yesterday. His mother doesn’t reply. Jack moves in front of the TV.  37.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I waited. His mother doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack furiously cycles through empty streets. Past identical suburban houses with identical prim lawns. He stops suddenly. Considering something. Then turns and cycles away purposely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot walks out of the funeral home. We pull back. Jack stands by his bicycle in the bushes watching him. Eliot looks up. As if sensing someone was spying on him. Jack steps back quickly behind a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POLICE OFFICER talks on the phone as Paul walks in.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hang on a sec. (to Paul) Mr. Conran. Heard about your girlfriend. I’m sorry. Paul nods. Clearly doesn’t want to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Is Tom in?

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: The captain just stepped out. He won't be long. You can wait in his office if you want.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thanks. I’11 just go and grab a coffee. As Paul walks away, the Officer returns to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: (into phone) A buddy of the captain’s. Poor guy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul slides a dollar bill into a coffee machine. Presses his selection. Nothing.  38.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Come on. He pushes the button repeatedly. Then angrily slams the side of the machine. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You piece of shit. As Paul turns away, he notices a door with a sign on it: AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL ONLY. Paul glances around. Then quickly walks over to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen wrecked cars. Twisted metal. Paul’s footsteps echo through the empty garage. It’s dark. Out the corner of his eye Paul glimpses a SHAPE move quickly around a pillar. He stops. Unsettled. Just then we hear a WOMAN’S FOOTSTEPS. Her high-heels clicking on the concrete floor. There’s something strange about the sound. UNNATURAL. Paul listens nervously. The footsteps grow fainter. Then fade away. The garage is silent again. Too quiet. Paul moves apprehensively over to Anna’s GREEN TOYOTA. The car’s a mess. One side’s completely caved in. He touches the car. Pulls open the door. Squeezes into the driver’s seat.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA'S CAR
dialogues.text: Glass everywhere. Paul glances at the KITSCHY BOBBLEHEAD DOLL on the dashboard flecked with blood. He places his hands on the steering wheel. Suddenly he hears a strange noise. He looks up... The KITSCHY DOLL. Its head NODDING SLOWLY. Its smiling face now unnaturally sinister. Turning towards us until it abruptly stops. Staring straight at us. Paul looks at the doll transfixed. Just then a PALE WOMAN’S HAND slowly reaches through the window... and touches Paul’s shoulder. He jumps. Turns. ANNA stands by the car. Staring blankly at him. The color drains from Paul’s face.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Paul? The Police Captain, Tom Peterson, stands by the car where Anna was a second ago. He pulls his hand away from Paul’s shoulder. Looks at him with concern.  39. Paul gathers his composure. He must have just imagined Anna was there. He shoves the door open. He’s about to step out when he turns back and grabs the Kitschy Doll.

dialogues.speaker: GARAGE
dialogues.text: Paul gets out awkwardly. He can’t look Tom in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You OK?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (unconvincing) I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I just found out. I’m so sorry Paul. If you need anything--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I need to see Anna.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (puzzled) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The funeral director won’t let me see her Tom. He says I’m not family. Can you talk to him? Put some pressure on him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I can’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Tom. You're my friend.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Paul. I can’t do it. Paul nods slowly. Tom notices the Kitschy Doll.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You sure you’re OK?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Paul. It was an accident. You should get some rest. Let me drive you home.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I always fuck everything up.  40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot stops by a thermostat. Studies it for a moment. Turns it lower. He glances at his watch. Takes out his keys from his jacket and moves over to the Prep Room door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sits on the slab. Her hands behind her back. She carefully watches Eliot as he pulls on his pale blue smock then walks over to a cabinet. BEHIND ANNA’S BACK her hands clutch the large scissors.

dialogues.speaker: PREP ROOM
dialogues.text: Eliot opens a cabinet full of boxes of hair dye with photographs of smiling women. As he prepares the dye he looks across at Anna. She’s staring at something behind him. Eliot turns. Sees the uncovered body of the Old Woman on the gurney. He quickly walks over. Carefully pulls the white sheet over the Old Woman.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Whitehall. He mixes the dye in a bowl as he moves over to Anna.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be afraid of her. The dead can’t harm the dead.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (forcefully) But I’m not dead! Anna’s hand suddenly FLIES UP... she slashes at Eliot’s face with the SCISSORS. The sharp edge misses his cheek by inches. Eliot drops the bowl. Stumbles back against the steel trolley. Instruments crash to the floor. Anna staggers to the door. Her legs weak. Her long lank hair falling over her eyes. She frantically wrenches at the door handle but it’s locked. Eliot gets up. Slowly moves towards Anna. She turns. Raises the scissors.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Stay where you are.  41.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (holds out his hand) Give me the scissors. I only want to help you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Don’t come any closer. I swear to God I’1l kill you. Eliot walks right up to her. His face now inches from her

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (calmly) Go ahead. Anna doesn’t move. Eliot looks her steadily in the eye. He reaches for her hand. Slowly. Deliberately. He brings the scissors to his cheek. Then lets go of Anna’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT'S FACE
dialogues.text: The sharp tip pushes into his skin.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: PREP ROOM
dialogues.text: For a moment we think she might do it. But then she waver

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: What are you waiting for? Anna’‘s confidence falters. She slowly lowers her hand. The scissors fall onto the floor. Anna looks down defeated. Her breath labored. Suddenly she realizes...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I'm breathing! (raises her head) Look. I’m still alive!

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You think you’re still alive because you’re still attached to life. It’s normal. You're just imagining you still have symptoms of life. She's not listening. Eliot takes a roll of paper towels. Kneels down, picks up the bowl of dye and mops up the mes

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Maybe I was in some kind of coma. The doctors made a mistake. They’re always making mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You died. Everyone dies.  42.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: How can I be dead if we’re talking? He stands up. Sighs wearily.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: We're talking not because you’re alive. But because I have a gift. (beat) I can talk to those between life and death.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: To help them make the transition. Anna’s stunned. For the first time we sense a seed of doubt in her mind.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Is this what happens when you die?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: It depends on how you lived your life.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Not everyone needs my help. Some let go as soon as their body dies. Others don’t let go until long after they’re in the grave.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Am I a ghost? Is that why I’m here?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You're here so I can bury you. Anna’‘s silent. Trying to make sense of what she’s just heard. Eliot takes her arm. Leads her to the slab.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Come. We've wasted enough time already. She lies down submissively. Suddenly very tired. Eliot leans over her to apply what’s left of the dye.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (whispers) No. Please. I don’t want--

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You're a corpse. Your opinion doesn’t count anymore.  43.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: But I can breathe. I must be alive. She weakly pushes him away. Anger flashes across Eliot's face, but just as quickly he controls it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You people. You all think that if you breathe, shit, piss you’re alive. Anna doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You clutch onto life as if your life was worth clutching onto. Was your life worth clutching onto Anna? Anna turns her head away. Clearly he’s struck a chord.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Was it? Maybe you died a long time ago. Eliot rips off his latex gloves. Tosses them into a bin.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I have to tell you I’m surprised you’re still arguing with me. You don’t have much time left. (gestures to the Old Women) Look. She’s accepted her death. Her life has been examined. She has no more regrets. And now she’s at peace. She used her time well. You still have so much to learn.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I have nothing to learn!

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Eliot stands in the doorway. He switches off the light. His body silhouetted by the light from the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Your funeral’s in three days. Soon you'll be enclosed in a coffin. Then buried in the ground. No-one will hear you then. No-one will talk to you there. The door clicks shut behind him. Anna doesn’t move. Clearly unsettled by Eliot’s words. After a moment she looks at the Old Woman. She moves over. Hesitantly pulls away the white sheet. Stares at the Old Woman curiously. Then tentatively touches her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Are you cold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the Old Woman’s hand. Strokes her paper-thin sk

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m so cold. Anna notices the Old Woman’s plastic ankle tag.

dialogues.speaker: ON PLASTIC ANKLE TAG
dialogues.text: Name: Carol Whitehall. Sex: F. DOB: 11.02.30.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You had a long life. Anna turns back. Studies the Old Woman’s serene face.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You look so peaceful. (beat) Aren't you scared? Anna’s eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m scared. I’m so scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack lies in bed staring at the ceiling. On his bedside table an alarm clock reads 2.38AM. He looks across at an Anglepoise lamp in the corner of the room bent over an op shoebox. He gets up. Walks towards the muted light. The SMALL CHICK huddles in the shoebox. It looks dead eve though it’s eyes are open. Jack’s about to reach into the box. Then changes his mind. He looks at the lamp. Switche it off. After a moment he switches it back on again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul stands motionless in the middle of the room. Staring blankly into space. The room feels empty and depressing. He suddenly looks around. Not quite sure why he came into the room in the first place. He moves over to a CD player Mechanically switches it on. Music fills the room. He turns the volume higher. Then all the way up. The music’s unbearably loud but Paul just stands there. Numb.

dialogues.speaker: ON PAUL
dialogues.text: The music’s strangely distorted now. Almost silent. As if we were inside Paul’s head.  45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna lies on the slab. Curled in a fetal position. 0.S. we hear the UNNATURALLY LOUD metallic drip of a faulty faucet. Slow. Rhythmical. Anna opens her eyes. Stares at us. Terrified. Then she turns her head. The Old Woman sits on the other slab. Slowly brushing her tangled gray hair with a silver backed brush. Anna looks around anxiously. The room is strangely larger. The perspective not quite right. Certain objects look absurdly small or abnormally large. She notices a TINY DOOR. Half hidden by a steel trolley. The door’s slightly ajar. Anna’s surprised. The Old Woman shakes her head. Staring blindly at Anna with opaque eyes. Anna ignores her. Moves quickly to the tiny door. As she approaches, the door seems to grow to normal size. Then we realize it’s Anna who has shrunk. The steel trolley now towers high above her. The massive instruments on the trolley look like menacing insects cast in surgical steel. She opens the door. Revealing a solid wall of DARKNESS.

dialogues.speaker: FROM INSIDE THE DARKNESS
dialogues.text: the small shape of Anna in the doorway. The huge dark space engulfs her. The only light comes from the Prep Room behind her.

dialogues.speaker: PREP ROOM
dialogues.text: Anna reaches forward. Her hand disappears into the thick blackness. She snatches her hand back. Scared. Then... ...a CHILD'S HAND darts out of the darkness. Grabs Anna’s wrist. Pulling her in with surprising strength. Anna struggles to free herself. But the hand drags her deeper into the darkness. The door slams shut behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna stands in the black empty space. GIRL’S VOICE (0.S.) I’m disappointed with you. An innocent looking YOUNG GIRL (6) materializes out of the blackness. She looks like a young Anna.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Who are you?  46. The Young Girl walks slowly towards Anna.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You promised me so many things. (amused) You don’t recognize me? Anna shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I am you. I’ve been waiting for you. You shouldn’t have disappointed me. The Girl now looks strangely malevolent. Anna steps back terrified. Turns. But there’s no door anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Woman stands alone in the middle of the room. Braiding her long hair.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: You're not ready. CUT TO A SEARING WHITENESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small congregation of MOURNERS sit in the white chairs. “AVE MARIA” plays quietly in the b.g. A MAN leans over the casket paying his respects.

dialogues.speaker: ON CASKET
dialogues.text: The Old Woman. Her long hair braided. She looks serene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “AVE MARIA” filters into the room. Anna opens her eyes. She’s confused. She gets up awkwardly. Looks around the room. The other slab’s empty. The Old Woman’s gone. Anna stumbles over to the trolley. Pushes it aside. Desperately searching for the tiny door. She touches the wall. There’s nothing there. Frustrated she turns to a counter crowded with instruments. She sweeps her arm across the counter top in rage. Sending everything crashing to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The funeral’s over. Eliot takes out a wilted bouquet of flowers from a vase.  47. In the b.g. Jack stands half-hidden in the doorway. Glancing around in fascination. A flower in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (to Jack without looking up) Can I help you? Jack steps back timidly. Eliot looks up. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Then perhaps you can help me. (holds up the withered flowers) Could you throw these away for me? Jack nods hesitantly. Moves over and takes the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Thank-you. Eliot turns and arranges fresh flowers in the vase.

dialogues.speaker: ON JACK
dialogues.text: as he looks at the wilted flowers. He crushes a petal then sniffs his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: There’s no life left in them.

dialogues.speaker: VIEWING ROOM
dialogues.text: Jack looks up. Eliot’s watching him carefully.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: They belong in the garbage. Jack turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’ve seen you round here before. Jack’s suddenly nervous.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Did you know Mrs. Whitehall?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I thought it was Miss Bryant’s funeral.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Ah. Miss Bryant. No. Her funeral’s not until Friday.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Where is she now? Eliot considers the question for a moment.  48.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: She’s downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Why? Because she’s not ready. (beat) Is the flower for her?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (nods ) She was my teacher.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: And you are?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Jack. Jack holds out his hand. A serious look on his face. Eliot’s amused. He shakes Jack’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Well Jack. What did you think?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Whitehall’s funeral. Did you find it interesting?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) It was OK I guess.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Oh. I see.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Are all funerals the same?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: No Jack. They’re never the same. Each one is special. The dead always speak to us in different ways.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (curious now) What do you mean? Eliot finished arranging the flowers. He glances at his watch. Smiles at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: It was a pleasure talking to you Jack.  49. Jack’s intrigued. He watches Eliot walk out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Eliot heads to the Prep Room, we hear a MUFFLED CRASH from inside. Eliot quickly pulls out his keys. Moves to the door. Just then Eliot hears a creaking sound behind him. He turns. Jack’s at the top of the stairs. Staring down curiously at the Prep Room door. Eliot observes him cautiously. Did Jack hear the sound as well? Jack looks back at Eliot. Smiles. Then without a word, turns and heads back up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sits on the floor in the middle of the room. Hugging her legs to her chest. Rocking to and fro. Surrounded by broken glass, torn papers and instruments. Eliot enters the room. Coldly surveys the destruction.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (angry) Why did you do this? Anna ignores him. Eliot strides over to her.

dialogues.speaker: WHY DID YOU DO THIS
dialogues.text: Anna stares at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Is this the afterlife? Am I in heaven? Or am I in hell? Strangely Eliot’s not surprised. He nods his head. His anger gone now.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: The door... (points distractedly) There was a door. Just there.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: gently) It won’t be long now.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I used to believe in God. I thought I’d see him when I died. Instead I saw you. Eliot softly strokes her hair. Comforting her.  50.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (whispers) Maybe you are God.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You'll be at peace soon. I promise. For a moment we see a deep sadness in Eliot’s eyes. He's conflicted. But then abruptly he pulls himself together. Moves away and starts clearing up. Anna closes her eyes. Hugs her legs closer to her chest.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Paul. She lets out a DESPONDENT SIGH. The SIGH carries into the next scene...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tall trees stand motionless amongst the graves. A sudden GUST OF WIND bends the dense foliage. Their leaves ripple. lLanguid and fluid like a wave. RUSTLING EERILY. The sound almost malevolent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul’s red-rimmed eyes snap open. He lies on his bed fully clothed. An empty bottle of bourbon on the bedside table. Behind him the curtains stir. The KITSCHY DOLL’S head begins to slowly nod. Turning towards us. We hear the eerie rustling sound again. Like a MURMURING WHISPER...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (whispers) Paul. Paul turns quickly. Sees the open window. It’s only the wind. He shivers. It suddenly got very cold. He gets up and closes the window. The WHISPERING starts again. This time from the bathroom. Paul walks over to the bathroom door. As he touches the door handle... the whispering STOPS. Paul hesitates. The room’s strangely silent. He slowly opens the door... INT. PAUL’S APARTMENT. BATHROOM —- CONTINUOUS Nothing. The bathroom’s empty. Paul looks around nervously. He catches the reflection of his pallid face in the mirror. lLeans wearily against the washbasin.  51. Water DRIPS from a leaky pipe. The fluorescent bulb over the mirror CRACKLES softly. Paul turns on the taps. Splashes cold water on his face. He’s about to reach for a towel when he senses something. He cocks his head slightly. A feeling. He turns and checks out the bathroom. Nothing. Paul dries his face. As he replaces the towel... the sound of dripping water ABRUPTLY STOPS. Silence. Suddenly the SHOWER STARTS RUNNING. Paul’s paralyzed with fear. Steam wreathes the room in a cloud of vapor. He turns slowly towards the shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna stands in front of the shower with her back to him. She slips off her bathrobe and hangs it on a hook. Then her hand moves to her chest. There’s a STRANGE WET SUCKING sound... .-..-as Anna rips out her heart and hangs it casually on the hook next to her bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STILL BEATING HEART
dialogues.text: dripping crimson blood onto the bone white tiles.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (whispers) Anna. Anna turns slowly. Her skin’s like alabaster. Unnaturally translucent. A bloody gash where her heart used to be. The steam from the shower curls around her like a mist. She looks hauntingly beautiful. Mesmerizing. A line of thick black fluid trickles from her nose. Paul turns away. Horrified. When he turns back a second later Anna’s not there. The bathroom’s empty. The shower’s not even running. INT. JACK’S HOUSE. KITCHEN - EVENING Jack opens the fridge. It’s almost empty. He takes out a carton of milk. Sniffs it. Recoils from the smell. From the living room we hear the LOUD sound of a TV.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (shouts ) Mom! We’re out of milk. There’s no reply. Jack grabs his jacket.  52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna‘s still sitting on the floor. The place is clean and ordered again. She watches Eliot unzip a garment bag. He lifts out a plain black dress.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: It’s your dress. For your funeral. Your mother brought it round this morning. As Eliot takes out a pair of shiny black shoes from a plastic bag, Anna moves haltingly over to the dress. She touches the material puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: This isn’t my dress. (realizes with shock) This is my mother’s dress! It was supposed to be for her funeral. Why has she given it to me? Eliot starts folding the plastic bag. He notices something else inside. He opens the bag. Hesitates then takes something out. ON ELIOT’S HAND An old-fashioned wooden rosary.

dialogues.speaker: PREP ROOM
dialogues.text: Eliot looks at it for a moment. Then glances over at Anna. She’s still staring at the dress. He opens a drawer beneath the counter. It’s full of rosaries and printed Holy cards. He quickly drops the rosary into the drawer. Closes it. Then turns back to Anna.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It should have been her not me. (turns to Eliot) She was the one dying. Not me. Eliot unlocks the door. Jams it open with a door stop. Slips his keys back into his jacket pocket. Takes off his jacket and hangs it up. He moves over to a collapsible gurney folded on the floor. Bends down and snaps open the side-rails. Anna looks at the open door.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m not ready to die. Eliot looks up at Anna sadly.  53.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Why are you still struggling?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (plaintively) I’m not ready to die. Not yet. She glances at the open door again. Eliot follows her loo

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: There’s nothing out there for you anymore. As Eliot turns back to the gurney, Anna notices Eliot’s jacket hanging beside her. Realizes the KEYS are in the pocket. She quickly glances back at Eliot. He’s still busy adjusting the gurney. She leans over to his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: ON ELIOT
dialogues.text: as he gets up and turns to Anna.

dialogues.speaker: PREP ROOM
dialogues.text: Anna looks at him calmly. We can’t tell if she managed to get his keys or not. Eliot pulls on his jacket and wheels the gurney through the door. He steps back into the room. Nudges the door stop away with his foot.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’ll be back soon. The door locks behind him with a CLICK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot pushes the gurney to a WHITE VAN with black tinted windows (Note: The same kind of van that cut in front of Anna just before the accident).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
