dialogues.text: Anna listens anxiously to the CRUNCH of Eliot’s feet on the gravel outside. After a moment she hears the van drive away. She unfurls her fist revealing Eliot’s keys. INT/EXT. ELIOT’S VAN. STREETS - MOMENTS LATER As Eliot slides in a CD he notices the fuel gauge. He’s low on gas. He glances into his rear-view mirror and makes a left turn.  54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna staggers to the door. There’s at least a dozen keys. She frantically chooses one and shoves it into the lock.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (begging the door to open) Please. It doesn’t fit. She’s panicking. She fumbles for another key. It almost fits. She forces it. The key SNAPS OFF LOUDLY in the lock.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No! Anna looks around desperately. Sees a tray of instruments on the steel trolley. She scrambles over. Finds a pair of surgical pliers. She moves back to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot replaces the pump nozzle. Walks over to the cashier

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Thirty-four fifty. In the b.g. Jack, a carton of milk in his hand, steps out of the gas station. Eliot doesn’t notice him as he pulls out a roll of notes. Hands over two twenties. Then he frowns. Something’s wrong. He checks his pockets again. He can’t find his keys. He walks quickly away.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Sir. Your change. Eliot ignores him. Scrambles into his van. Intrigued, Jack watches Eliot drive away. Then unlocks his bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna’s still trying to pry out the broken key.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (desperately) Come on. Come on. INT/EXT. ELIOT’S VAN. STREETS - SAME TIME Eliot’s at a red light. Drumming his fingers in frustration as he waits for the light to change.  55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally Anna pulls out the broken key. Quickly chooses another. Turns it gently. Again it doesn’t fit. Anna's hysterical now. She tries the next key. It fits! She’s stunned for a second. Then pulls open the door. INT/EXT. ELIOT’S VAN. STREETS - SAME TIME Eliot turns sharply into a small road by the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna staggers to the front door. She pulls at the door. It won’t open. Frantically she finds the key. Unlocks the door, leaving the keys in the lock. As she opens the door HEADLIGHTS sweep across the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot’s van pulls up in front of the house.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE HALL
dialogues.text: Anna’s trapped. We hear the CRUNCH of Eliot’s footsteps on the gravel outside. Anna looks round desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot reaches the front door. It’s slightly ajar. He pushes it open. Steps warily inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot looks around. The entrance hall’s empty. Then he notices the keys in the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dark. Anna pulls at the back door. It won’t budge. She panics. Sees a kitchen knife on the counter. Quickly grabs it. As she steps back, she knocks over a metal bucket. The sound’s DEAFENING in the silent house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot hears the NOISE. Smiles. He calmly locks the door and puts the keys into his pocket. Moves down the hallway towards the kitchen.  56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot switches on the light. The kitchen’s empty. He steps back into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands very still. Watching. Waiting. We pull back.

dialogues.speaker: JUST AROUND THE CORNER
dialogues.text: Anna pushes herself against the wall clutching the knife.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Eliot turns towards her... then at the last moment changes his mind. Heads in the opposite direction towards the viewing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot steps carefully into the viewing room. Looks around. Just then we hear the sound of bare feet STAMPING along the hallway behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna runs to the front door. It’s locked. She glances around anxiously. Sees a staircase leading upstairs. She weakly stumbles up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna walks along the corridor. She peers into a room. Notices a TELEPHONE on a table. She moves over to the telephone. The door CREAKS closed behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot hears the CREAKING DOOR upstairs. He cocks his head upwards. Straining to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna frantically punches the buttons on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A telephone RINGS in the empty kitchen.  57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna rocks back and forth as she anxiously listens to the RINGING on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (desperately) Please pick up. Please pick up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot slowly climbs the stairs. INT. PAUL’S APARTMENT. KITCHEN - SAME TIME The phone continues to RING. We pull back. Paul stares at the phone blankly. A drink in his hand. He looks worse than before. Dark circles under his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna glances back to the door in panic.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Paul. Please pick up. INT. PAUL’S APARTMENT. KITCHEN - SAME TIME Finally Paul reaches across and picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna cups her hand around the mouthpiece.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (frenzied whisper) Paul. I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Help me Paul. Anna’s HOARSE DISTORTED VOICE sounds almost malevolent. Paul’s stunned. He stares at the phone as if it was possessed. Then slowly puts it down.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Leave me alone.  58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks at the phone in disbelief. The MONOTONOUS TONE DRONES in the ear piece. She doesn’t notice Eliot appear in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Paul. Suddenly the light comes on.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’m the only one who can hear you now. Anna drops the phone. Backs away towards a window. Eliot walks over and calmly replaces the phone.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’d be very careful if I were you. The dead have such a hold over the living.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (nods to the phone) He still feels your presence. You're only causing him more pain. If you really loved him, you'd accept your death and let him go.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Then prove to me I'm really dead.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You people. You always need proof. Eliot places his hands on her shoulders. Turns her towards a tall mirror.

dialogues.speaker: ON MIRROR
dialogues.text: A PALE CADAVEROUS WOMAN. Sunken eyes. A blood-stained tear in the side of her RED SLIP.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS ROOM
dialogues.text: Anna’s stunned. She moves closer to the mirror. Touches her reflection through a thin layer of dust.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Why do I look like a corpse?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Because you are a corpse.  59.

dialogues.speaker: ON MIRROR
dialogues.text: Anna stares blankly at her image in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: It's time you finally accepted the truth. You are dead. You will never live again.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I am dead.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS ROOM
dialogues.text: Eliot smiles. Like a father proud of his child’s first step. Just then he notices something outside. We see a brief flicker of unease in Eliot’s eyes. ELIOT’S POV Jack stands in the driveway holding his bicycle. Looking up at the Funeral Home. Transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK’S POV Anna in her RED SLIP by the mirror. She looks frightening in the harsh light. Deathly pale. Like a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVEWAY
dialogues.text: Strangely Jack isn’t scared. He continues staring up at the window. Calmly. Curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot coolly turns back to Anna. She hasn’t noticed Jack. Still staring at her reflection in the mirror. INT. PAUL’S APARTMENT. KITCHEN - MOMENTS LATER Paul stares at the telephone. After a moment he slowly pulls the telephone plug out of the wall. Mechanically grabs a plastic bin liner from underneath the sink. INT. PAUL’S APARTMENT. BEDROOM - MOMENTS LATER Paul opens the wardrobe. Pulls out Anna’s clothes. Stuffs them into the bin liner. He notices the Kitschy Doll. Shoves it in with Anna’s clothes.  60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna lies on the slab. She stares at us blankly. Her face emotionless. Resigned. Eliot rinses her hair now dyed back to brown. She slowly closes her eyes. CLOSE ON RED DYE draining into the sink. Eliot picks up the scissors. Carefully slices open Anna's red slip. Delicately peels the slip off her body. Anna doesn’t react. CLOSE ON Anna. She opens her eyes. Confused. She turns her head... she’s in PAUL’S BEDROOM. INT. PAUL’S APARTMENT. BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS Paul lies in bed next to her watching her intently. He looks different. Clean shaven. Sober.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (relieved) Oh God.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Bad dream?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I was dead. I had a car accident. Did you ever dream you were dead? Paul doesn’t reply. She turns... the bed's empty.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Yes? Anna looks up. Paul’s in the doorway. She gets up. Suddenly the light goes off.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Paul. The light comes back on. Paul stands by the light switch.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (puts his finger to his lips) Ssh. Don't talk so loud. You'll wake the neighbors.  61. Anna’s getting nervous. Something’s not right.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What neighbors? You don't have any neighbors. Suddenly he looks at her reproachfully.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did you ever love me Anna? CLOSE ON Anna’s face. She looks away guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Did you? Anna closes her eyes. Unable to answer.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Say it. Say you love me. Suddenly we hear the strident ringing of a phone.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Aren’t you going to pick it up?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Me? No. It’s probably for Eliot. Anna’s eyes snap open in shock... INT. FUNERAL HOME. PREP ROOM —- CONTINUOUS Eliot stands over her. We’re back in the PREP ROOM. We hear the faint ringing of a phone from upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Is it always like this?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I thought when you died you wouldn’t feel anything. You wouldn’t feel any more pain. You wouldn’t have to struggle anymore. (beat ) But it just doesn’t stop does it? Upstairs the phone keeps on ringing.  62. INT. FUNERAL HOME. ELIOT’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER Eliot takes notes as he talks on the phone. He looks at a day calendar on his desk. Idly flips over the page from Tuesday to Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: No. It’s no problem at all. He glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’‘ll pick up the deceased from the hospital. Yes. This afternoon? That‘1l be fine. It’s my pleasure Mr. Merano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAY BODIES lie on steel tables. Eliot moves over to one of the CORPSES. Examines it with professional interest. Just then the Old Guy walks in with the Pale Assistant pushing a gurney with a BODY wrapped in plastic sheeting.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY
dialogues.text: Well here he is. Frank Merano. The Old Guy hands Eliot a clipboard. The Assistant unties the rope. Pulls the plastic sheeting away.

dialogues.speaker: ON BODY
dialogues.text: FRANK (40s), the top half of his head has been flattened. His head split open. Grotesquely distorting his face.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Ouch. That had to hurt.

dialogues.speaker: MORGUE
dialogues.text: Eliot glances at the Assistant with disdain. Signs the release form and hands the clipboard back to the Old Guy. INT. ELEMENTARY SCHOOL. TEACHERS’ COMMON ROOM —- DAY Paul stands by a PRINCIPAL as they watch a JANITOR snap off the padlock on Anna’s locker.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: (to Paul) I’‘1ll leave you to sort out her things.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thank you.  63. The Principal and Janitor walk away. Paul reaches inside the locker. Pulls out a stack of exercise books. An empty pills bottle. Then he notices something in the back of the locker. He pulls it out. It’s a PHOTOGRAPH of Paul and Anna together on vacation. Smiling. Happy. Paul looks at it for a moment. Trying hard to hold back his emotions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DEAFENING NOISE of schoolchildren. Paul weaves his way through the crowded corridor.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Conran?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (turns) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: My name's Jack. Miss Bryant was my teacher. (beat) I saw her last night. Paul looks at Jack coldly for a second. Then walks away. Jack follows him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I was going past the funeral home. Miss Bryant stood there. In the window. Ina red dress.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (irritated) Anna doesn’t have a red dress.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You think I’m lying. I’m not lying. Paul stops. Turns to Jack angrily.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Look... (trying to remember his name) Jack. I’m in no mood--

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: She needs your help.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (shouts ) Jack. Anna’s dead. Paul’s words ECHO loudly. The bustling corridor goes sile  64.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) I can’t help her anymore. Paul turns and walks away. Jack grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Maybe you just don’t love her anymore? Paul turns and hits Jack with the back of his hand. Jack falls to the ground. Paul stands over him enraged.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You little fuck. You think this is funny? He’s about to hit Jack again when a STOCKY TEACHER grabs him. Paul tries to struggle loose.

dialogues.speaker: STOCKY TEACHER
dialogues.text: Hey! The CHILDREN stare at Paul. A SECURITY GUARD runs across talking into a walkie-talkie. Another TEACHER bends down.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Are you alright sweetie? Jack nods numbly. Looking up all the time at Paul. The Security Guard grabs Paul’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: The police are on their way. Paul watches Jack stand shakily. Realizes what he’s done. He reaches out to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Jack... I’m sorry...

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Step back sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sits at a table. Staring blankly at a row of CCTV monitors. The door opens. Tom walks in.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You're lucky.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Am I?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: They’re not pressing charges.  65. Paul doesn’t look up. He’s miles away.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What the hell’s wrong with you? (holds his fingers close together) You're this close to fucking up your career.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (suddenly looks up) You know what he told me? He told me Anna's alive.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You didn’t believe him did you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No. Of course not. Tom’s relieved. Paul turns back to the monitors. The ghostly figure of a YOUNG FEMALE TEACHER drifts hypnotically across the screen.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s just... I’m having these...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nothing. Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot leans over Frank’s body on the slab. Rolling a ball of wax in his hands to warm it up. He gently moves Frank’s head to one side. In the b.g. Anna lies on her slab watching Eliot work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stares back at her with open dull eyes. His face partially reconstructed with plaster of Paris.

dialogues.speaker: PREP ROOM
dialogues.text: Eliot smooths the wax over the plaster to give Frank’s face a more natural texture. Then picks up a piece of wire with a fishhook-like barb at each end.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: What’s that for? Eliot looks up surprised. Anna stands beside him. He leans down. Peels back Frank’s upper lip.  66.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: His mouth. To keep it closed. Eliot imbeds one barb into the upper gum then pries back Frank’s lower lip. He attaches the other barb into the lower gum, then twists the wires tightly together. He picks up two plastic caps covered in small knobs.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Now his eyes. He inserts the caps into Frank’s eyes. Pulls his eyelids over them. Glues the eyelids together.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Is this how you’1ll prepare my body? Eliot looks at her for a moment. Smiles reassuringly.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: No. There’s no need. I had to rebuild his face. You're still beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Does he have family?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Yes. A brother. He’s coming in later. Anna touches the white sheet covering Frank’s body.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: My mother... She didn’t cry did she? When she came to see me?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: And Paul?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: It’s not important anymore.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I need to know.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (hesitates) No. He didn’t cry. We see a brief flicker of pain in Anna’s eyes.  67.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I knew he wouldn’t. He always got upset when I cried. He said crying never helped. Anna suddenly looks very weary. She leans heavily against the slab. As if she’s about to fall.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You should rest. He guides her back to the slab. Helps her lie down.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You're getting weaker. It’s almost time. Eliot strokes her hair tenderly. She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Why do we die? A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: To make life important. Anna's fingers curl around his hand. Like a vulnerable child. Totally trusting in him. Eliot looks down at Anna sadly. We sense he’s conflicted. Confused. Wavering. But then reluctantly he reaches for a SYRINGE filled with AMBER LIQUID on the steel trolley. He injects her gently in the neck. Watches over her for a moment. Then moves to the window. He picks up a window pole. Pulls the shutter across the window plunging the room into darkness

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot moves through the Funeral Home pulling heavy drapes over the windows and closing doors. It feels like a ritual. The once airy sunlit rooms are darker now. More ominous. Claustrophobic. INT. FUNERAL HOME. ELIOT’S ROOM - DAY CLOSE ON a stream of crystal blue water. We pull back. Eliot picks up a white towel. Dries his hands. Deep in thought. He moves to his desk. Picks up a Polaroid.  68.

dialogues.speaker: ON POLAROID
dialogues.text: The Old Woman, Mrs. Whitehall, lying in her casket.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Whitehall. Susan. I hope you found what you were looking for.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: Suddenly Eliot looks up sharply. As if someone had spoken to him.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Think nothing of it Mr. Houseman. No need to apologize. Eliot moves over to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I really enjoyed our time together. We pull back slowly. Eliot’s talking to a POLAROID of an OLD MAN. We pull back further... the wall’s covered in HUNDREDS OF POLAROIDS of BODIES in open coffins. Most of them have closed eyes but we glimpse some with their eyes wide open. Eerily staring at us. Eliot touches the Polaroid of a YOUNG MAN. We see the fear in the Young Man’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Anthony. Anthony. Always confused. Just then we hear the doorbell ringing downstairs. Eliot moves to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POLICE OFFICER stands at the front door. A SQUAD CAR parked on the driveway. ELIOT’S ROOM Eliot steps back. Calmly continues to dry his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot leads the Police Officer through the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: How can I help you Officer?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: I’d like to see the body.  69. Eliot stops. We see a brief flicker of unease in his eyes

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Frank Merano. I’m his brother. Vincent Merano? I called this morning.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Mr. Merano. Yes. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (OFFICER)
dialogues.text: I hope it’s no trouble. I’d just like to see him before the funeral. Eliot glances at his watch. Smiles at Vincent.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: It’s no trouble at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot leads Vincent to Frank’s covered body. Vincent looks over at Anna. The white sheet only comes to her shoulders, her head facing straight upwards.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Your brother's here. Vincent turns back to Eliot. We’re not sure if Eliot was speaking to Frank or to Vincent. Eliot pulls the sheet away. Frank’s face is flawless. No sign of any damage.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: He looks so peaceful. You’ve done a beautiful job. Thank-you.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You should remember him as he used to be. Suddenly we hear a FAINT RUSTLING sound. Vincent glances again at Anna's body. Her head is now turned to one side. Wasn't she facing upwards a moment ago? Vincent’s puzzled for a second then shrugs. Must have been his imagination.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That’s the schoolteacher isn’t it? Eliot pulls the sheet over Anna's face.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (quickly) Yes. Very tragic. Now is there anything else I can help you with? Vincent frowns. Turns back to Eliot.  70.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Something’s not right here.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (looks up sharply) Not right? Vincent nods towards Frank's body.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: His smile. It was a bit more... Vincent raises his fingers to his mouth, trying to find the right word.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: ..-smiley.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Smiley.

dialogues.speaker: ON FRANK'S MOUTH
dialogues.text: Eliot manipulates Frank’s lips.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: A touch more.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: That’s much better. Thank-you.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’m glad I could help.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I have a couple of minutes alone with him? Eliot hesitates. Then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: No. Not at all. I’11 wait outside. As Eliot leaves, Vincent looks at Frank’s body. After a moment he glances at Anna again. Then at the door. He quickly moves over to Anna. Looks at her curiously then pulls down the sheet. He reaches over... and CARESSES HER BREAST. Mesmerized by her naked body. As Vincent’s hand moves down her body, he bumps against the trolley. Instruments CRASH to the floor. He pulls back the sheet just as Eliot enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I didn’t see...  71. Eliot notices the sheet covering Anna’s body is slightly askew. He reaches over and straightens it. Then looks coldly at Vincent. There’s an uncomfortable silence.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Well. I guess I should be off then. I’11 see you at the service. Thanks again. Vincent glances one last time at Anna then leaves. The door locking shut behind him. Eliot stares at the door.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I just told you. That was your brother. (turns to Frank) You had an accident. You’re dead. Why do you people never listen to me? Frank doesn’t move. His mouth still wired shut.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: No. It's not a gift. It's a curse. Eliot picks up a compact. Roughly layers Frank’s cheeks with thick rouge. With every word he gets more agitated.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I take care of each of you as if you were my children. I wash the shit from your bodies. I dress you. I do everything to make you look more beautiful than when you were alive. And what do you do? Eliot’s extremely irritated now. He grabs a garish red lipstick. Smears Frank’s lips.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You argue with me. As if it were my fault you’re dead. As if I was to blame. (slams down the lipstick.) What? You’re not talking to me now? You don’t want to? ON FRANK’S FACE The crudely drawn bright red lips. Clown-like circles of rouge. Gaudy and macabre.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don't talk because you have nothing to say. And you have nothing to say because you’re a corpse.

dialogues.speaker: PREP ROOM
dialogues.text: From Eliot’s reaction it seems as if Frank has started to talk again.  72.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: No. Now I don’t want to talk to you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The curtains are drawn. Jack’s Mother, still motionless, in front of the blaring TV. Jack stops in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’m off to school now. His mother doesn’t reply. Jack leaves. After a moment she slowly turns her head. Stares at the empty doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack cycles through the cemetery. He pulls up by a bush. Stares at the Funeral Home in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The service hasn’t started yet. Jack walks nervously through the empty room to an open casket. He glances back, then leans over the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Merano lies nestled in the velvet interior. His face placid. No sign of the gaudy make-up.

dialogues.speaker: VIEWING ROOM
dialogues.text: Jack stares in fascination at Frank’s body. He reaches into the casket. Touches Frank’s cold hand. In the b.g. Eliot walks into the viewing room. He stops surprised. Watches Jack intently.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (to Frank) What’s it like? Are you afraid?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: VIEWING ROOM
dialogues.text: Jack turns quickly. Eliot stands over him.  73.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You have empathy with the dead. You’re drawn to them. Just as they’re drawn to you. It’s a rare gift. Jack can’t look Eliot in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I know you saw Anna. Jack hesitates. Then nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You're frightened by it. I was scared too the first time. But you shouldn’t be. Christ had the same gift. He raised Lazarus and spoke to the dead.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (intrigued) You spoke to Miss Bryant?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You've spoken to others?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Yes. Many others.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Who was the first one you spoke to? A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: My mother. Jack looks up sharply. Eliot’s words have clearly struck chord.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be afraid. (beat) The others. They won’t understand. They don’t see what we see. (beat) I can help you. I can teach you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna stares vacantly at the ceiling. Eliot places a bunch of tulips on the trolley. Turns on a CD. CLASSICAL MUSIC fills the room as before. He moves over to Anna. Gently Pulls away the sheet.  74.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Your fingernails are dirty. Eliot smiles. Examines his nails.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Your hands are normally so clean.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’ve been gardening. He walks over to the sink. Scrubs his nails.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Is it sunny outside? Eliot fills a bowl with water. Carries it to the slab.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Yes. The tulips love the sun.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I miss the sun. Anna glances up at the shuttered window. Eliot snaps on his latex gloves. Picks up a sponge and wets it in the bowl of water. Anna turns to the tulips.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Are they your favorite flower?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Tulips? Yes. I think so. Eliot raises Anna’s arm. Delicately washes her armpit. Along the length of her arm. Her skin pale.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I thought it’d be lilies. White lilies. Don’t they symbolize death?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: No. They symbolize purity. He moves to her breasts, following the contours of her body. Pausing every now and then to rinse the sponge.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: And tulips? Eliot hesitates for a second before replying.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Unrequited love. (beat) What’s your favorite flower?  75.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Violets. Eliot softly washes her legs.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: A beautiful flower. They need shade and lots of water.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What do they symbolize?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Faithfulness.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (distractedly) Do they? Eliot puts down the sponge. Dries her body with a towel.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Roses are red, violets are blue... He reaches over to the CD player to switch it off.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No. Leave it on. It’s so peaceful. Eliot smiles. Leaves the music on. INT/EXT. PAUL’S CAR. STREETS - DAY Paul drives aimlessly past strip malls. He stops at a red light. Lights a cigarette. Just then he notices something across the street. He looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul gets out of his car. Quickly walks over to the store window.

dialogues.speaker: ON STORE WINDOW
dialogues.text: A RED-SLIP on a mannequin. Just like ANNA’S RED SLIP.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: The light’s turned green. The DRIVERS HONK angrily. Paul doesn’t hear them. He places his hand against the plate glass. Stunned.  76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot prunes a low hedge by the front door.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Deane. Eliot turns. Paul’s clearly agitated.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Mr. Conran. A pleasure. Eliot stands stiffly. Rubs his back.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I love gardening, but I’m not sure gardening loves me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She’s not dead is she?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (amused) Mr. Conran.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Someone saw her.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: One of Anna’s students. (nods towards the funeral home) In the window.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Do you mean Jack? Paul’s momentarily taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You know him?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Of course I know him. He’s often round here. He seems to have a strange fascination with death. He's eleven years old Mr. Conran. And like all young boys has a vivid imagination. Now if you'll excuse me--

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I don’t think he imagined it. I think he really saw her.  77.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Maybe you just want to believe he saw her.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Paul pushes past Eliot and strides into the Funeral Home.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Mr. Conran!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul moves quickly through the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (shouts ) Anna! Eliot calmly heads towards Paul.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Mr. Conran. I think you should leave before I call the police. Paul notices the stairs leading down to the Prep Room.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What’s down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul runs over to the Prep Room door. He grabs the handle It’s locked. Eliot appears behind him. Paul turns.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She’s in here isn’t she? Give me the key. Eliot stares at Paul with pity.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Give me the fucking key. Paul turns back. POUNDS the door in rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The POUNDING echoes through the room. Anna awkwardly sits up. Struggling with her emotions. She wants to call out but knows she has to let Paul go.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Anna!  78. Anna gets up. Hesitates. Weakly stumbles to the door.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m here Anna. (desperate) I’m sorry. Please Anna. He places the palm of his hand against the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna places her palm against the door. As if touching Paul’s hand. A tear falls down her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We'll be happy again. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can’t live without you. Eliot looks up at Paul with sudden interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna shakes her head. Takes her hand away from the door. Walks back to her slab.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Anna! Eliot gently puts his hand on Paul’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Mr. Conran. She’s dead. Paul pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I know what you’re going through. Denial’s a natural part of grieving...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna lies down on the slab. Closes her eyes. ELIOT'S VOICE seems far away now. Receding.  79.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: .»..-but you’ve got to accept she’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She needs my help. Eliot looks at him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You can’t help her anymore. Believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open plan office. Paul weaves quickly through the rows of desks. He seems unbalanced. Manic. DETECTIVES cautiously watch Paul approach Tom sitting at his desk, his head bent over paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I need you to issue a search warrant. Tom looks up. He’s shocked by Paul’s appearance.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (loudly) I need a fucking search warrant. Now are you going to help me or what? JEFF (20s) a Young Detective at a nearby desk stands. Tom nods to him. It’s under control.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Paul. Sit down. Paul hesitates for a second.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (firmly) Sit. Down. Paul sits. Tom leans forward. He’s not amused.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Just what the hell do you think you’re doing? I got a call from Eliot Deane. Are you out of your fucking mind?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Anna’s not dead Tom. He won’t let me see her. He’s keeping her there--  80.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Anna was in a car accident. Her car was wrecked Paul. Remember? It’s downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She’s not dead. Tom calmly gets up. Moves to a filing cabinet. Takes out a file. Hands it to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Here’s the Coroner's report. Paul manically rifles through the file.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Look. (shows file to Tom) The paramedics phoned it in. They only checked for eye dilation and pulse. The doctor signed the death certificate without even seeing her body.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (irritated) So? That’s standard procedure.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: There was no EEG. Nothing. He could have drugged her to make it look like she was dead.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Drugged her? Are you serious? Jeff looks up eagerly from his desk.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: There are drugs like that chief. Hydronium Bromide. Total paralysis within seconds. The heartbeat slows to almost nothing. Tom shoots Jeff a look.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: See? I’m telling you. She’s not dead. The boy at school. Jack. He saw her.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I saw her. Paul turns hopefully. Finally someone believes him. Vincent Merano stands by Jeff’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: She was on the slab. Dead.  81.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I’ve seen dead bodies. Believe me, she was definitely dead.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Tom. Just go down there and check the place out.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: On what grounds Paul? Do you have any evidence?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No. But--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Do you have anything? Paul hesitates. We sense his uncertainty.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I think she called me.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Called you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (weakly) On the telephone. Jeff snickers. Paul’s beginning to realize how absurd this all sounds.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Collect or long distance? Jeff snorts with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: First you hit a fucking kid. Then you attack Deane. And now you’re telling me your dead girlfriend called you? What the fuck’s going on? You’re loosing it Paul. Merano and Jeff shake their heads, looking at Paul as if he were crazy. Tom’s voice softens.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I know you feel guilty but you’ve got to pull yourself together. Paul slumps in the chair. Rubs his face.  82.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Maybe you’re right. But why won’t he let me see her? Tom signals to Merano and Jeff. Merano walks back to his desk. Jeff turns back to his work.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Look Paul. The funeral’s tomorrow. You'll see her then. It’ll help. It will give you closure. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun’s low on the horizon. Eliot whistles softly to himself as he digs a grave. Working meticulously. Like everything else he does. Suddenly a SHADOW falls over Eliot. He calmly looks up. The sun’s behind the figure. For a moment Eliot can’t tell who it is.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You said you could teach me. Eliot smiles. Gestures to Jack to come inside the grave. Jack steps back. The grave terrifies him.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: It’s only a hole in the ground. I’m digging it for--

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Miss Bryant.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Exactly. For Anna. She belongs here.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Because she’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: No. Because there’s no life left in her. Jack carefully considers Eliot’s words.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Don’t you see? I have no choice. I’m the only one who can see all these corpses. Wandering the earth aimlessly. All they do is piss and shit. Suffocating us with their stench. Doing nothing with their lives. Taking the air away from those who actually want to live. I have to bury them all. I have no choice. (beat) Now there’s two of us.  83. Eliot holds up the shovel. Jack looks at him for a moment then reaches for the shovel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna watches Eliot brush an invisible speck off her mother’s black dress.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You did well this morning.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: This morning? She talks with difficulty now. Her voice SLURRED and HOARSE. Her words muddled and rambling. Her eyes even more sunken. Her skin even more pale.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: When Paul came. You did the right thing. You let him go.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: He’1l be all right now? Won’t he? Eliot looks away. Doesn’t reply. He drapes the dress over his arm, picks up a pair of shiny black shoes and moves over to her.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (confused) Why do I have to get dressed?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Tomorrow’s your funeral. Eliot lifts Anna’s arms and puts them through the sleeves of the dress. Her body’s stiff and unyielding.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Already?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I told you. You only had three days. He delicately turns her onto her side. Buttons up the dre

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I told you to use your time well. Anna frowns. As if trying to remember something. Eliot gently lifts her legs. Pulls on a pair of black tights.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I need to... I have so many regrets. I have nothing but regrets.  84. She looks up at him. Suddenly realizing.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: That’s why I’m here isn’t it? To be judged. Eliot picks up Anna’s shoes. Slips them onto her stiff fe

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You’re here to understand your life. So you can finally be at peace.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I wanted a different life. Eliot picks up a nail-clipper. Gently holds Anna’s hand as he carefully cuts her long nails.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Then why didn’t you do anything about it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No matter what I did everything just stayed the same. I’d wake up. I'd shower. Sit in the same traffic everyday on my way to work. Go home. Go to sleep. Then wake again. Eliot stops clipping her nails. Irritated.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: What did you really want from life?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I just wanted to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (derisively) Happy? You all say you wanted to be happy. What does it mean Anna? To be happy?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Don’t you understand? That’s the whole point. I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Yes you do! You’re just too scared to admit it to yourself. Anna turns away ashamed. She knows he’s right.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don’t want to talk about it anymore. I just want this to be over.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: What did you want from life?  85.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don’t fucking know!

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (screams back)

dialogues.speaker: I WANTED LOVE
dialogues.text: Anna’s stunned. She’s finally admitted it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (quietly) I wanted love.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You had love. Paul loved you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No. You don’t understand. I was scared. I wanted to love but I didn’t know how. I was... (beat) When I was a child... my mother. Anna struggles to pull together her thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: When I was a child. I learnt that love. That when you love someone. You get hurt. So I learned not to love. That way no one could ever hurt me again. She looks down at the slab. Touches the cold marble.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I was always pushing Paul away. He thought I didn’t love him.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: He was the only one I ever loved. But I never told him that. And then he stopped loving me. Eliot stares at her intently. Comes to a decision.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: What would you do if you had another chance? Anna‘s puzzled. Eliot goes to the door and unlocks it. Moonlight floods in from upstairs. Washing it with a cold light. Anna doesn’t move.  86.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Well? Isn’t this what you wanted? Eliot holds out his hand. Anna takes it hesitantly and rises from the slab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mist drifts through the cemetery. Anna stands in the driveway. Pale and ghoulish in her black funeral dress and shiny black shoes. She starts walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna approaches her mother’s house. Paul opens the door. He’s not surprised to see her. Beatrice stands just behind him. A black shawl over her head and arms. INT. MOTHER’S HOUSE. HALLWAY - NIGHT In the candlelight we can see the house is full of OLD WOMEN. Their faces deeply lined. Wearing identical black shawls. They stare at Anna, whispering in different rhythms. Unintelligible words undulating like an ANCIENT PRAYER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Beatrice lead Anna to the bed. As she lies down we realize the bed is full of BLACK SOIL. Clouds of ugly flies hang in the air. BUZZING noisily. The Old Women surround Anna in a tight circle. Leaning over her. Making her feel claustrophobic. She can smell their rotting breath as their prayers grow LOUDER. Through the chaos of words we begin to make out...

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMEN
dialogues.text: Spit it out. Anna doesn't understand. Then she feels something in her mouth. Growing. Gagging her. The Women are SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMEN
dialogues.text: Spit it out. Anna spits out... white maggots. She gags again. Closes her eyes. Shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna’s eyes snap open. She’s still in the Prep Room. She steps back from the doorway. Terrified.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I thought you were different. You all Say you’re scared of death. But the truth is you’re more scared of life. Eliot switches off the lights.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I’m glad I’m dead. I’m glad it’s over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sits in his car. Staring out at the Funeral Home as he nervously smokes a cigarette. The light in Eliot’s room goes off. Paul waits for a moment. Then gets out of his car. Stubs out his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul treads carefully along the side of the Funeral Home. It’s a full moon. The trees rustle ominously in the wind. Casting eerie shadows against the dark house. He finds a window. Tries to open it. It won’t budge. Just then he hears a noise in the bushes. He crouches down quickly. Listens hard. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE BUSHES
dialogues.text: Someone watches Paul tentatively move to another window.

dialogues.speaker: FUNERAL HOME
dialogues.text: Paul strains to open the window when suddenly... he’s caught in a circle of bright light. Paul turns quickly. A DARK FIGURE stands over him. Menacing.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing here? The Figure lowers the flashlight. It’s Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m taking you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON black earth. A trowel digs into the soil.  88. We pull back. Jack’s just finished digging a hole in the flower bed. A shoebox beside him. He takes off the lid. The Chick trembles in the corner of the box. Jack slowly replaces the lid. Puts the box into the grave. He pushes the earth over it. The box jerks. We hear the faint RUSTLING of the Chick inside.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Don’t be scared. It’s better this way. INT. FUNERAL HOME. ELIOT’S ROOM - DAWN Eliot lies on his bed. Dressed in a dark suit. He hasn’t slept at all. His eyes rimmed red. He checks the clock on the bedside table. It’s 4.30am. He glances to the window. Dawn light seeps into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot walks through the garden. A pair of small secaters in his hand. He stops by a bed of violets. Still covered in morning dew. He kneels and starts cutting the delicate flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna lies on the slab in her burial dress. Her eyes close Eliot enters the room. He doesn’t lock the door behind him. Doesn’t turn the lights on. Doesn’t change into his mortician smock. He approaches the slab. The violets in his hand. Pulls over a chair and sits next to Anna. Places the violets on the steel trolley beside her. He looks at her intently. For the first time he seems uncertain. Vulnerable. As if questioning himself. After a while he suddenly gets up and heads towards the door. He’s about to close the door behind him...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I don’t even know your name.

dialogues.speaker: ON ANNA
dialogues.text: Her eyes still closed.

dialogues.speaker: ON ELIOT
dialogues.text: Eliot pauses. Too confused to look back at her.  89.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: It’s... (beat) It’s not important. He closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Beatrice’s face. Her eyes closed. A HAND delicately powders her forehead. As if she's being prepared for her own funeral. We pull back. Beatrice, dressed in black, sits in front of a mirror. Diane applies her make-up. Beatrice opens her eyes. INT. PAUL’S APARTMENT. BATHROOM - DAY Paul, badly shaven, leans against the washbasin. Wearing a crumpled black suit. Staring vacantly in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna lies in a casket as Eliot arranges her hair.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (gently) It’s time now. She looks up smiling. Eliot positions her hands, entwining her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You have to look beautiful for your funeral. He picks up a SYRINGE and an ampoule of AMBER LIQUID. Fills the syringe.

dialogues.speaker: ON AMPOULE
dialogues.text: We glimpse the label: HYDRONIUM BROMIDE.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: This will relax your muscles. Make your skin radiant. As if you were still alive. Just sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: This is how they’1l all remember you.  90.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Can I see myself for the last time? Eliot smiles. Picks up a mirror. Hands it to Anna.

dialogues.speaker: ON MIRROR
dialogues.text: Anna looks peaceful. Beautiful. Serene.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Is this the end?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: The last part is the most difficult. You’1ll have to face it alone. But you’ll be at peace soon. Anna nods. SIGHS deeply... her BREATH FOGS the mirror. She frowns. Touches the SMALL CIRCLE OF CONDENSATION on the glass. Looks up at Eliot in shock.

dialogues.speaker: PREP ROOM
dialogues.text: Eliot glances anxiously at the fogged mirror, then at Ann

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You lied to me.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Anna. We've been through this before. You're just imagining--

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You lied to me. Eliot injects her in the side of the neck. Anna tries to raise her hand to push him away but she’s too weak.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: You’re still clutching onto life. Don’t give in to your fears. You’re so close. Anna’s fading away. Her hand drops limply to her side.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (whispers) Why did you lie to me? She stops struggling. Stares blankly at us. Eliot looks at her for a moment. Sadly. Regretfully. He picks up a Polaroid camera. The flash explodes in a blinding white light. He pulls out the Polaroid. Peels off the front and fans it in the air. Then...  gl.

dialogues.speaker: ON ANNA
dialogues.text: ...-delicately closes Anna’s eyelids.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Good bye Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna’‘s funeral is in progress. Eliot stands by her casket. Surrounded by wreathes of tulips and lilies. Beatrice, in her wheelchair, in the front row. Diane beside her. A SCHOOLTEACHER sits behind them with Jack and other CHILDREN.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER GRAHAM, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I am the resurrection and the life. Those who believe in me, even though they die, will live. Tom and Paul appear at the door. Tom guides Paul to a seat near the back.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER GRAHAM, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: They that sleep in the earth will awake and shout for joy; and the earth will bring those long dead to birth again.

dialogues.speaker: ON CASKET
dialogues.text: Anna lies in an open casket. Her eyes closed. She can hear the DISTORTED VOICE of the Priest.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER GRAHAM, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: We have come here today to remember before God our sister Anna. To give thanks for her life.

dialogues.speaker: ON ANNA'S FACE
dialogues.text: We see an almost imperceptible frown.

dialogues.speaker: VIEWING ROOM
dialogues.text: Eliot gestures to Beatrice. Diane wheels her to the caske Beatrice looks at Anna for a moment, then touches the violets in Anna’s hands.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Violets. They were her favorite flowers. (turns to Eliot) How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Violets just seemed appropriate somehow.  92. Next we see Mrs. Hutton at the casket. Then Jack. He stares at Anna’s body before being moved on by the Schoolteacher. Finally Paul and Tom approach the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks serene.

dialogues.speaker: VIEWING ROOM
dialogues.text: Paul takes out the ring box from his pocket. Gently slides the engagement ring onto Anna’s stiff finger. Suddenly he looks alarmed. Turns quickly to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (whispers) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She’s so cold. Paul turns back to Anna. Tears prick his eyes. He touches her cheek again. Finally accepting her death.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Anna. He kisses her lips. Eliot watches him carefully. It's almost as if he's jealous. Jack notices Eliot’s look then turns and stares at Paul. As Paul and Tom walk away Eliot closes the casket. Begins to screw down the lid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dark. We hear the screws TIGHTENING. Anna's eyes FLICKER OPEN then close again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then Paul turns back sharply. As if he sensed Anna’s reaction inside the casket. Tom gently stops him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) She’s at peace now. Paul glances at the casket again, then reluctantly allows Tom to lead him away. Eliot tightens the last screw. His back to the room. Suddenly the screwdriver slips. Gashes his finger.  93.

dialogues.speaker: ON COFFIN
dialogues.text: A drop of blood falls onto the polished wood.

dialogues.speaker: VIEWING ROOM
dialogues.text: Eliot stares at the blood for a moment. Takes out a pristine white handkerchief. Carefully wipes off the blood. Then places his hand on the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (softly) Don’t be scared. It’s better this way. Eliot turns. Signals to the PALLBEARERS standing nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pallbearers slowly lower Anna's casket into the open grave. The casket lurches as it settles in the grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna’s eyes SNAP OPEN in terror. She tries to scream out. But only a SOFT RATTLING WHISPER escapes from her throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TEACHER throws a handful of earth onto the coffin. Jack steps up. Looks down curiously. As if he could sense Anna. Then slowly pours the soil from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER GRAHAM, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: We have but a short time to live. Like a flower we blossom and then wither. In the midst of life we are in death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blackness. Earth CLATTERS HEAVILY onto the wooden lid. Anna GASPS softly. Hyperventilating. The earth keeps falling. The sound becoming SOFTER with each shovelful. She struggles. Bangs her fists against the wood. EXT. CEMETERY. ANNA’S GRAVE - LATER The grave’s covered with a stone slab now. Votive candles flicker on top. In the b.g. MOURNERS head to their cars. Paul and Tom stand by the grave.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You sure you’re going to be OK?  94.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks Tom. Tom squeezes Paul’s shoulder then walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot carefully pins Anna's Polaroid to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ON POLAROIDS
dialogues.text: We pan slowly across the other photographs we saw before. But now we look at them differently. In some faces there is the glimmer of life. In some a despairing pleading look. In others passive resignation. ELIOT’S ROOM Eliot moves towards the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dark cemetery. In the distance flickering candles illuminate Anna’s grave.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Imagine Anna. The whole world, your mother, your fiancée, your friends. Everyone has buried you. They've placed a stone above your body. ELIOT’S ROOM

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: They've said their good byes and gone back to their TV dinners and shopping malls. Thinking that this is never going to happen to them. Until it’s their turn to be buried. Think about it Anna... Eliot glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: ...think about it while you still can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul unlocks his car. He’s about to open the car door when he feels someone watching him. He turns. Jack’s observing him carefully.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You said she was alive.  95.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I never said she was alive. I just said I saw her. Paul simply nods his head. Too drained of emotion to reac

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You need a ride? Jack shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: OK. See you. Paul opens the car door.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Mr. Conran? (Paul turns) Don't forget to fasten your seat belt. Paul nods. Gets in his car. Jack looks up at the Funeral Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot stands in the window smiling at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're at Anna’s wake. PEOPLE talk quietly in small groups Paul fills a glass with whiskey. Knocks it back in one. PEOPLE stare disapprovingly. WHISPERING to each other.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Don't you think you've had enough to drink? Paul turns. Eliot stands beside him. Paul pours himself another drink.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Go to hell. An ELDERLY COUPLE shake their heads and walk away.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: (amused) Mr. Conran. We’re at a wake. You should show more respect.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I know she wasn’t dead.  96.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Wasn’t she? Eliot’s suddenly tired of Paul’s allegations.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Mr. Conran. You come to my Funeral Home, making wild accusations. You have no idea what happens when someone dies. What happens to their body. What happens to their soul. (taunting) You think Anna was alive after the accident? Maybe you’re right. Paul’s stunned.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Maybe she’s still alive. You obviously don’t believe a word I say. So why don’t you go and find out for yourself Mr. Conran. Find out whether she’s alive or dead. Paul grabs Eliot by his lapels. Shoves him against the wa

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (loudly) You twisted fuck. The room’s SILENT. Everyone turns towards Paul. Eliot whispers in Paul’s ear.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You don’t have much time left. Father Graham puts his hand on Paul’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Please. Paul. You're not well. Paul pushes his hand away. Eliot shakes his head sadly. Everyone looks at Paul with pity as he runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sprints across the lawn to his car. INT. PAUL’S CAR - NIGHT Paul slips his key into the ignition. His hand’s shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot watches Paul’s car ROAR OFF.  97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can’t see a thing. But we can hear Anna’s SHORT SHALLOW GASPS. And the sound of her nails desperately SCRATCHING at the coffin lid. INT/EXT. PAUL’S CAR. ROAD - NIGHT Paul drives fast. Accelerating then quickly braking as he weaves through heavy traffic. He comes up behind a slow Tractor-Trailer. Hits the HORN.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Come on. Come on. He swerves into the middle of the road. There's a blind curve ahead... suddenly an SUV comes out of the corner. A bright white light sweeps through his car. Paul's momentarily blinded. THE SCREEN FLASHES TO WHITE. Paul opens his eyes. The ROAD’S EMPTY. No sign of any traffic. He’s confused. The road was busy a moment ago. Just then flashing red and orange lights illuminate the car. Paul looks in his rear-view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: ON REARVIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: An AMBULANCE moves quickly towards him. Blasts past.

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: Paul looks through the front windshield. Nothing. He frowns. Where did the ambulance go?

dialogues.speaker: UP AHEAD
dialogues.text: We see the Funeral Home. Bone white in the moonlight. The cemetery next to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot’s White Van sits by the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul’s car slams to a halt. He jumps out. In the distance the candles still burn on Anna's grave.  98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul grabs a shovel by the grave. Starts digging. Then the shovel clunks against wood. He kneels down. Scrapes away the earth from the coffin. Then pulls open the lid. Anna's eyes are WIDE OPEN. Her fingernails torn and blood Paul grabs her shoulders. Pulls her out of the grave. Her body slumps limply like a rag doll.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Anna. I’m here. Please God. Anna. He desperately tries to revive her. But there’s no life left in her. He’s about to give up when... Anna’s hand TWITCHES. Then after a moment she GASPS. Her eyes slowly focus on Paul.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Baby. Thank God. Paul gently helps Anna to her feet. She looks round. Dazed. Turns back to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You came back for me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I came back for you. You're safe now.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (smiles) Promise. Just then Paul hears a rustling sound behind him. He turns. Nothing. He cocks his head slightly. There’s something unnerving about the silence. Suddenly a CROW rises noisily into the air. Paul starts. Then watches, relieved, as the crow disappears into the dark sky. He turns back to Anna... she’s not there.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Anna? Paul looks round desperately. Runs between the stone crosses and statues of grieving angels searching for her.  99.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Anna! Just then he glimpses SOMETHING MOVE among the trees. Runs over. Nothing. The cemetery is empty. The trees appear to SHIMMER for a moment. Paul shivers. Pulls his jacket around him. He doesn’t notice the candles on Anna’s grave behind him suddenly BLOW OUT. INT/EXT. ELIOT’S VAN. ROAD - NIGHT We hear the sound of a SIREN. The AMBULANCE blasts past. Eliot slides a disc into the player. CLASSICAL MUSIC fills the van. He strums the wheel. Enjoying the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul frantically runs into the parking lot. still calling out for Anna.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Anna! Suddenly the interior light in his car comes on. Paul looks at the car nervously. He heads over to it. Apprehensive. Then... the car door slowly CLICKS open. Paul stops. Stares into the car. There’s no one there. INT. PAUL’S CAR - MOMENTS LATER Through the windshield we see Paul approach the car. He peers in nervously. Then cautiously gets in. As he switches the interior light off, the camera moves slowly around him revealing... ... ANNA sitting in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Are we going home? Paul turns sharply. Stunned. Anna moves towards him.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Or do you want to make love here?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where did you go? Anna puts her fingers on Paul's lips. Clearly turned on. We hear the sound of something being UNZIPPED.  100.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (whispers) I’ve been waiting for you. I missed you so much. A line of BLOOD trickles from his nose. He touches his lips. Looks blankly at the blood on his fingertips. A drop of blood falls on Paul’s white shirt. It unfurls like a flower. Spreading out over the material.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I love you. I always did. Anna hungrily kisses him. He responds passionately. Suddenly we hear a SHARP METALLIC SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (alarmed) What was that? Anna responds as if it was nothing strange.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It's only the scissors... We see the growing anxiety in Paul's eyes. Anna's just interested in his lips.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Scissors? What scissors?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Scissors. For your clothes. Eliot just put them on the table. Paul pulls back. Terrified.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You're safe now. We’re finally together. A strong bright light sweeps across Paul’s face. Like the headlights of the car on the blind curve earlier. FADE TO SEARING WHITENESS. Paul blinks as he gradually gets used to the harsh light. Slowly the room comes into focus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliot stands over Paul holding a pair of BLOODY SCISSORS. Paul looks down. His white shirt soaked with blood, the material sliced open.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where am I?  101. He talks with difficulty. His breath labored.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You’re in a funeral home. (beat) You’re dead.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m not dead. Jack appears at Eliot’s side.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You had a car accident. You swerved off the road. On the way to the cemetery. Hit a tree.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I saw Anna. You buried her alive.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Mr. Conran. You never made it to the cemetery. You never saw Anna. You’re dead. Paul’s glazed eyes widen in shock.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m not dead. Eliot speaks calmly. Soothingly.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: Your skull was crushed. Your spinal cord pulverized. Your brain cells are slowly dying. Your body’s already decomposing.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m not dead. Eliot sighs wearily. He's had this conversation many times before.

dialogues.speaker: ELIOT
dialogues.text: You people. You all say the same thing. Eliot's voice, with each word, fades further and further away. Paul closes his eyes. FADE TO SEARING WHITENESS.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m not dead. FADE OUT.
